loans.name: Josephine B.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Josephina N. from Mbeya. She is married and has three children between the ages of 1 and 13. She is also responsible for supporting one dependent whose parents cannot care for her. 

Josephina has been running a genge business since 1999. "Genge" is the Swahili word a type of outside shop or stall. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood with a tin roof where the proprietor sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place where local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

Josephina works at her business for 12 hours per day, 7 days per week, and is assisted by two employees. Josephina currently earns about $51 USD each month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $800 USD to purchase more sugar, kerosene, soap and cooking oil in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity of goods in order to get more profit from her business . Josephina thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more sugar, kerosene, soap and cooking oil in bulk

She is requesting a loan of $625 USD to purchase more stationary materials for her business. In the future, she plans to open the same business at a new location. Lilian thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Hroon

texts.en: This is Hroon son of M. R. who is 25 years old. He is married and the father of two children. He lives with his family in Sukhrood in Nangarhar province. He is a responsible person and supports his family. He is a tailor and has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. Now he wants to enlarge his business and he needs a loan of 50,000 (AFN) with a term of 12 months. With this loan he will buy a tailoring machine and clothes for his shop. He is very happy about this provision of loans for poor people in poor countries like Afghanistan and he thanks AFSG in Afghanistan and all the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Buy a tailoring machine and clothes for his shop

loans.name: Esrarullhaq

texts.en:
Esrarullhaq, son of Y. M., is 24 years old, single and lives with his family in a household of eight members in the Nangrahar province. Esrar has been working as a farmer, growing vegetables for the last several years in his village, but he studies up to six classes in the police in Jalalabad city.

Esrar is the only one to support the whole household.  Also in his spare time he helps his small brother who goes to school. Esrar dreams of his brother studying for his higher education and so he wants to increase his income to help.
  
Esrar needs a 50000 AF loan for buying some seeds and other essentials for his land. He is very thankful to get a loan from AFS as he could not get the money anywhere else and is very happy to be able to follow his dreams.

loans.use: Buying seeds for his land to grow more vegetables

loans.name: Noorullhoda

texts.en:
Noorullhoda, son of A., is 26 years old. He graduated from grade 12 six years ago. At that time he faced some problems that prevented him from continuing his studies. Now he lives in Jalalabad. He is a very hard worker and has a shop selling mobiles in the city.


Noorullhoda lives with his parents in a small house. His life is going well, but Noor has dreams of enlarging his business  and also wishes to become a businessman in the future, bringing in more mobiles from foreign countries like Pakistan and China. His parents pray a lot for him.


Now he needs a 50,000 AFN loan to purchase mobiles for his shop, but no one is present to give him a loan this size. He thought a lot about who could lend him the money until one day when his friend saw some information about AFS. As a result, he contacted the lenders of AFS to take out a 50,000 AFN loan , and now he is very thankful to all the lenders and to AFSG in Jalalabad, Afghanistan.

loans.use: Buying mobiles and necessary items for his shop

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 55-year-old man who lives in Saida, in southern Lebanon with his wife and their six children. Ahmad has been selling fruits and vegetables since 1996. Ahmad is a mobile seller. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a small van for his work. The van will facilitate his work and his moves. This is the first time that Ahmad has requested a loan.

Ahmad is special in his work because he goes into regions where no mobile salesman goes. His clients are his friends, neighbors, and others. When Ahmad first started his business, he didn’t have enough cash. He decided on doing this business because he needed to improve his family’s income. In the future, he plans on expanding his business and maybe opening a shop.

loans.use: To purchase a small van for his work.

loans.name: Naisi

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Naisi M. from Tukuyu. She is married with a one-year old child. Naisi has been running a wholesale & retail shop since 2003. Her business is to purchase commodities at wholesale and sell them at a higher price to the people around her. She works at the business for 9 – 12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Her husband assists her. Naisi currently earns about 250USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase more sugar, cooking oil, soap, wheat, flour and rice in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and the range of her business. Naisi thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Olipa A.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 41-year-old Olipa M. from Tukuyu. She is divorced with three children between the ages of 13 and 25. Olipa has been running a bar since 2004. Her bar is a good place to chill with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. It’s the kind of place where you kick back on a plastic chair under a tree, with a local beer in hand, the aroma of roasting ‘mishikaki’ (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to anyone and everyone who happens to wander by.

She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Two employees assist her. Olipa currently earns about 200USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase more crates of beer, soft drinks, and other drinks, like whisky, for her business. In the future, she plans to open the same business in a new location. Olipa thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase more crates of beer, soft drinks, and other drinks for her business

loans.name: Rebecca G.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 40-year old Rebecca K. from Mbeya. She is single with two children, between the ages of 10 and 14. She is also responsible for supporting one dependant because he is an orphan. Rebecca has been running a local restaurant known as “mama lishe” since 1998. When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Four employees assist her. Rebecca currently earns about $250 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $550 USD in order to make improvements to her restaurant and quality. In the future, she plans to start a new business. Rebecca thanks you for your support!

He requested a loan of $1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase beans for his restaurant. This is the first time that Mahmoud has requested a loan. Mahmoud is speciA. in his work because his restaurant is clean and he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. When he first started his business, he didn’t have the startup capitA. and he couldn’t find a strategic place to open his restaurant. He decided on this business because he always wanted to open a restaurant and he likes the contact with clients. In the future, he plans on expanding his business and starting a second business.

loans.use: To purchase beans for his restaurant.

Ruth thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future

loans.use: To buy rice, beans, flour, cooking oil, and sugar in bulk

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 35-year-old man who lives in Saida, Southern Lebanon with his wife and their child. Ahmad has owned a sweet shop since 2004. He sells Lebanese sweets. Ahmad requested a loan of $500 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw materials and change the décor of his shop. This is the first time that Ahmad has requested a loan.

Ahmad is special in his work because he is known for his sweets. His clients are his friends, neighbors and people from his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of networking. In the future, Ahmad plans to purchase his shop.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and change the décor of his shop.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a 39-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Ibrahim has been working as a mason since 2000. Ibrahim requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work and reimburse his debts.

This is the first time that Ibrahim has requested a loan. He is special in his work because he values punctuality and good work. He decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on working on bigger projects.

loans.use: to purchase tools for his work and reimburse his debts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stock of clothes in bulk

loans.name: Violet A.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 22-year-old Violet D. from Mbeya. She is single. Violet has been running a piggery project since 2009. Her business is raising pigs and selling the products. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 7 days per week.

Violet currently earns about US$ 250 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 625 USD in order to purchase pig feed, etc. In the future, she plans to increase the number of pigs for her project. Violet thanks you for your support!

One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed, etc.

loans.name: Tina G.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 39-year-old Tina C. from Tukuyu. She is married with two children, 14 and 17. Tina has been running a local restaurant known as “mama lishe” since 2007. When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

Tina works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, and is assisted by one employee. Tina currently earns about 100 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase more rice, beans, salt, sugar and maize flour in bulk. In the future, she plans to open a new business. Tina thanks you for your support!

One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more rice, beans, salt, sugar and maize flour in bulk

loans.name: Rehema V.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Rehema M. from Tukuyu. She is married with 2 children, 4 and 8. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because their parents passed away of HIV AIDS.

Rehema has been running a timber business since 2006. She buys timbers from farmers and sells them in town for a profit. She works at the business for 9 - 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Rehema currently earns about 60 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase more timber in bulk. In the future, she plans to establish a new business. Rehema thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Lupi M.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Lupi S. from Tukuyu. She is single with 2 children. Lupi has been selling maize since 2000. A typical maize business is a stand on the side of the road where maize is often piled high in baskets. Customers can scrutinize the quality of the product before purchase and specify the exact amount they would like to purchase. Maize is very important to the Tanzanian culture as maize is used to make one of their staple dishes, ugali, which is made solely of maize flour and water.

Lupi works at the business for 9 - 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Lupi currently earns about 500 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase more maize in bulk. In the future, she plans to open the same business at another location. Lupi thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase more maize in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more rice, sugar, cooking oil and maize flour in bulk

loans.name: Tukulamba M.

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Tukulamba K. from Tukuyu. She is married with two children, ages 4 and 10. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one other dependent because he is an orphan.

Tukulamba has been running a crop-selling business since 2006. Her business is to purchase a variety of crops in the villages and sell them in the town for higher price. She works at the business 12 hours per day, seven days per week and is assisted by her husband.

Tukulamba currently earns about $70 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase more varieties of crops in bulk. In the future, she plans to open the same business at another location. Tukulamba thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Mariamu K.

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 53-year-old Mariam J. from Tukuyu. She is married with four children between the ages of 34 and 40. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting three dependents because one is an orphan while the others' parents cannot take care of them.

Mariam has been running a genge since 2002. A genge (grocery store) is usually a very basic structure made of wood with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

She works at the business for 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her husband. Mariam currently earns about $20 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase sugar, rice, salt, and beans in bulk for reselling. In the future, she plans to open another business. Mariam thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, rice, salt and beans in bulk for reselling

loans.name: Gulnafisa

texts.ru: Гулнафиса ранее торговала продуктами питания и уже получала займ на КИВА. Несколько месяцев назад она поменяла вид деятельности и совместно со своими 3 подругами она открыла свадебный салон в центре города Канибадам. Буквально в эти дни она и ее подруги отремонтировали помещение салона и выставили свадебные платья. Ее деятельность заключается в подготовке невест к свадебному торжеству и включает в себя весь спектр услуг: стрижка, маникюр, окраска волос, сдача платьев в прокат и так далее. Гулнафис уже имеет много свадебных платьев но хочет приобрести несколько новых моделей и поэтом подала заявку на КИВА.
texts.en:
Gulnafisa used to sell food and have already taken out loans at Kiva. A few months ago she has changed her business and together with three of her friends has opened a bridal store in the center of the city of Kanibadam. Just a few days ago she and her friends has finished remodeling the salon and has put out gowns for display. Her work consists of preparing the brides for the wedding ceremony and includes the entire range of services: hairstyling, manicure, hair coloring, renting out wedding gowns and etc. Gulnafisa already has many wedding gowns, but wants to get a few of new styles and this is why she applied at Kiva.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy new wedding gowns

loans.name: Lebia M.

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Lebia M. from Tukuyu. She is married with four children between the ages of 1 and 12. Lebia has been running a shoe-selling business since 2007. Her business is to purchase shoes on a wholesale basis and sell them on a retail basis.

She works at the business for 12 hours per day, six days per week. Lebia currently earns about $100 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase more shoes in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and the range of her business. Lebia thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA

loans.use: To purchase more shoes in bulk

loans.name: Issomadin

texts.ru: Исомаддин работает преподователем в средней школе. Ему 50 лет, он женат, имеет 5 детей. Кроме основной работы Исомаддин имеет мельницу по переработке зерна в муку. Если не иметь дополнительного источника дохода то в нынешнее время не выжить. Цены на продукты питания и промышленные товары высокие, а заработной платы преподователя на все не хватает. Сейчас Исомаддин планирует закупить зерно для чего подал заявку на КИВА.
texts.en:
Issomadin S. is a middle school teacher. He is 50 years old, married, and has five children. Beside his primary job, he also has a grain mill for producing flour. Without additional income he would not have been able to survive. Prices for food and consumer goods are high and a teacher's pay does not cover expenses. Now Issomadin has applied to Kiva for a loan to buy grain.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grain for mill

loans.name: Medelina A.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 38 year old Medelina N. from Tukuyu. She is married with 4 children, between the ages of 9 and 18. Medelina has been running a tailoring and clothes business since 2002. She purchases vitambaa (material), vitenge (a traditional Tanzanian cloth with wax print), and kanga (printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides) and makes them into clothing mainly for women.

She works at the business 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Medelina currently earns about 363USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase more fabric and clothes in bulk. In the future, she plans to open the same business at another location. Medelina thanks you for your support!

This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more fabric and clothes in bulk

loans.name: Rebeka

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 35 year old Rebeka M. from Tukuyu. She is married with 3 children, between the ages of 5 and 15. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting 2 dependants because their parents died of HIV.

Rebeka has been running a crops selling business since 2003. Her business purchases crops from farmers and sells them in town for a higher price. She works at the business 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Rebeka currently earns about 65USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 325USD in order to purchase bags of rice and beans in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and the range of her business. Rebeka thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. loans.use: To purchase bags of rice and beans in bulk

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.ru: Мухабат живет с мужем, ей 59 лет. Оба спруга находятся на пенсии, но она такая маленькая и приходится заниматься предпринимательством. Она продает варенный горох на центральном рынке. Ее муж готовит горох дома, а она реализует его. Варенный горох популярное блюдо у таджиков и поэтому прибыль остается хорошая. У Мухаббат имеется постоянное торговое место на центральном рынке. Кроме того Мухаббат и ее зять держат маленький продуктовый магазин по месту жительства. Мухаббат планирует уевличить свой оборотный капитал и поэтому подала заявку на КИВА.
texts.en:
Muhabbat lives with her husband. She is 59 years old. Both spouses are retired, but their pension is small and they must be entrepreneurs. She sells boiled peas at the central market. Her husband prepares the peas at home and she sells them. The peas are a popular food among the Tajiks, so her income remains good. She has a permanent sales place at the central market. In addition, Muhabbat and her brother in law keep a small grocery store where they live. Muhabbat decided to increase her working capital and apply for a loan from Kiva.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For purchase of peas wholesale

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 32 year old Stella M. from Tukuyu. She is single. Stella has been running a grocery business since 2006. She owns a small duka, a neighborhood shop, in the city where she sells common household and grocery items.

She works at the business 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, and is assisted by two employees. Stella currently earns about 100USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase goods for her shop. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity of goods in her shop. Stella thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase goods for her shop

loans.name: Saboat

texts.ru: Сабоат занимается куплей продажей различных промышленных товаров на центральном рынке города Исфары. Ей 46 лет, постоянной работы у нее нет и занятие бизнесом единственный источник ее дохода. Кроме этого в летний период она занимается переработкой абрикосов. В Микроинвест она получала займ для переработки абрикосов. Погашения этого займа недавно закончились. Условия кредитования Микроинвест ей понравились и поэтому она решила получить новый займ для увеличения оборотного капитала своего бизнеса, продажи промтоваров.
texts.en:
Saboat sells various manufactured goods at the Isfara central market. She is 46 years old and has no permanent employment, so business is her only source of income. In addition, she also works processing apricots during the summer. She received a loan from Microinvest for the apricot processing, and finished repayment of it recently. She liked Microinvest's terms so she decided to obtain a new loan in order to increase her sales business's working capital.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Lilian J.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 30 year old Lilia M. from Mbeya. She is married with 2 children, between the ages of 1 month and 2 years old. Lilian has been running Agricultural Inputs since 2006. Her business purchases agricultural equipment in wholesale bases and sells them to farmers in retail bases.

She works at the business 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Lilian currently earns about 188USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 800USD in order to purchase more agricultural equipment in bulk for reselling. In the future, she plans to open the same business at another location. Lilian thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more agricultural equipment in bulk for reselling

loans.name: Sobirboy

texts.ru: Собирбою 55 лет, он женат и имеет 5 детей. Уже много лет он занимается ремонтом велосипедов в своей мастерской недалеко от центрального рынка. У многих людей в городе и деревнях велосипед является единственным транспортным средством и поэтому у Собирбоя всегда много клиентов. Каждый день от 10 до 15 человек обращаются к нему. Для Собирбоя данная деятельность является единственным источником дохода для его семейного бюджета. Собирбой планирует обновить свои инструменты в мастерской и поэтому подал заявку на получение займа.
texts.en:
Sobirboy is 55 years old, he is married and has five children. For many years he has a business repairing bicycles in his shop not far from the central market. Many people in the city and villages use bicycles as main transportation and this is why Sobirboy always has many customers. Every day around ten to fifteen people come to his shop. For Sobirboy this business is the only source of income for his family. Sobirboy plans to buy new tools for his shop and this is why he applied for a loan.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy new tools

loans.name: Seng's Group

texts.en:
The group of borrowers consists of four members. Its leader R., 33, is a mother of four children, all of whom are single and under her care. She is married to Dieng, 36, who earns a living fishing along the Mekong river. R. is a fish seller in the market since 2000. She has a lot of customers because her store is located in the busy market. She gets up early every morning to gather the fish from her husband at the riverside and also buys some fish from other fisherman. She resells the fish for a good price. She wants to have a small table for her fish selling so that she can increase her family's income. R. is taking a loan to buy a small table and to pay for her store in the market.

The group includes the following members. K., 53, is a fish trader who is looking for a loan to invest in her business. H., 64, earns a living selling cooked ingredients and is applying for a loan to buy more cooked ingredients for her store. K., 43, earns a living fishing along the riverside and is looking for a loan to buy more fishing web. They all live in Siem Reap Province.

loans.use: To buy a small table and to pay for her store in the market

loans.name: Lam's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of five members. Its leader N., 37, is the mother of three children, all of whom are single and under her care. She is married to Khun, 40, who is a motor taxi driver. N. has served as a farm worker since 1999. She is well-known for working hard and being a responsible neighbor. N. is taking a loan to buy a new motor for her husband's business, because the old one has been causing difficulties. The loan will help the family with its transportation needs and will also help them attain a better standard of living. 

The other members of the group are: N., 42, who works in a massage center, and is taking a loan to build a house for herself and her family; S., 52, who serves as a firewood provider, and is taking a loan to buy some poles for her new house; N., 55, who sells traditional Khmer noodles to the whole community, and is applying for a loan to invest in her business; and L., 19, who works in a massage center, and is requesting a loan to buy more wall slides for her house. They all live in Sienm Reap Province.

loans.use: To buy a new motor for her husband's business

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Leng P., 39, lives in the Siem Reap province with her husband and four children. She and her husband are farmers, making US$3 a day, and are supported by her child who is a worker making US$2 a day. In light of these times of economic difficulties, Leng P. is asking for a loan of US$600 to purchase wood to sell. She is an ambitious entrepreneur who one day hopes to set up a grocery store in front of her home. She sees this loan as a way to increase her income and is confident that her business venture will be successful.

loans.use: To purchase wood to sell.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: Srey K., 38, lives in the Siem Reap province with her husband and two young children. She makes about US$2.50 daily, selling wood and growing rice, while her husband helps her with planting the rice. She is asking for a loan in the amount of US$500 to purchase more wood. She is also hoping to purchase a pig to raise and sell with the money from the loan. She sees this loan as a great opportunity to expand her business and is confident that she will see her income increase as a result.

loans.use: To purchase wood to sell.

loans.name: Eng's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of four members. Its leader, K., 28, is single and lives with her sister who helps K. with her business. K. owns a general store in front of her house and sells plastic, charcoal, small tools and cooking ingredients, among other items, and she has been in this business since 2000. She buys her products from the province's market in bulk and sells at a reasonable retail price to the community. She sells all of her products from the store. She wants to renovate the store to increase the size of her business. To do that, K. is asking for a loan to buy more products for her general store. 

The other group members are: H., 53, who works as a dish seller in a private sector, and is taking a loan to buy more poles for her house; Kimchhhom, 22, who is a local construction worker, and is taking a loan to build a house for his family; and K., 48, who serves as a local police officer, and is taking a loan to buy more cooking ingredients for her daughter. They all live in Siem Reap Province.

loans.use: To buy more products for her general store

loans.name: Sous

texts.en: Sous S., 36, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo, Cambodia. She works as a weaver and makes US$3 per day, while her husband earns US$3 a day working as a taxi driver. This couple has no children yet. Sous S. would like to take out a loan to purchase silk to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase silk.

loans.name: Penn

texts.en: S. is 49 years old and a resident of Siem Reap Province. She has five children, all of whom are single. Three of them work in the labor industry and the other two are students. S. is married to Sok, 45, who earns a living catching fish along the Mekong riverside. S. has been a fish seller in the Psar Tom market since 2000. She gets up every morning early to gather fish from her husband and then hurries to sell them in the market. Sometimes she takes her children to help with her husband's fishing. S. wants to increase the number of fish her husband catches, so she is taking a loan of $300 to buy more fishnets. The loan will help the family attain a better standard of living. She dreams of her children having a degree and of a big house for her family.

loans.use: To buy more fishnets for her husband's fishing

loans.name: Min

texts.en: Min S., who is twenty-nine years old, is a professional tailor and lives with her husband in the Bati, Takeo province. She typically makes $2 every day, while her husband works as a garment factory worker and earns $3 per day. This couple has four children, two of whom are students and two who are too young to attend school. Mim S. would like to take out a loan to buy a cow.

loans.use: Purchase a cow

loans.name: Chheng

texts.en: Chheng P. is forty-two years old and resides with her husband in Takeo, Cambodia. To earn a living, she works as a weaver and makes $3 per day. Her husband has worked as a farmer growing rice and vegetables since 1991, and is able to make $2 per day. This couple has three young children. Chheng P. is asking for a loan to purchase silk and other materials to expand her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk.

loans.name: Preas

texts.en:
P. is a 53-year-old resident of Siem Reap Province. She has six children: one is married and lives separately; one works as a tour guide with his tourist car; and the other four are students. She is married to Lon, 63, who is a local construction foreman.

P. is a traditional Khmer noodle seller in the Cung Kneas market. She has been in this business since 2002 and she earns up to $5 per day. She is famous for she is good at making tasty cuisine of her noodles.

She wants to have a shop with a comfortable location in the market so that she can serve her customers more kindly. P. is looking for a loan of $1,000 to build a shop for her noodle-selling business and to renovate her house for her family. She dreams to have degrees for her children and a big house for her family.

loans.use: To build a shop for her noodle-selling business and to renovate her house

loans.name: Lay

texts.en: Lay V. is forty-one years old and sells silk cloth in the Bati, Takeo province. She usually purchases silk cloth from the Bati district and resells in the market at Phnom Penh. On average, she makes $3 per day. Her husband stays at home and weaves silk scarves. He typically makes $2 a day. This couple has two children, one who is a student and one who is a weaver. Lay V. would like to take out a loan to purchase silk cloth to resell at Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To purchase silk cloth

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mao S., 42, is married and lives in the Takeo province of Cambodia. Since 2000, she has been weaving to earn a living and is able to make $2 per day. Her husband is a worker and typically earns $3 a day. This couple has four children, three of whom are in school and one who is working.

Mrs. Mao S. is asking for a loan to purchase silk so she can weave more silk clothes to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase silk

loans.name: Nhor

texts.en:
Nhor S., 32, is a blacksmith and resides with his wife in the Takeo province of Cambodia. He has operated this business for four years and typically makes $50 in revenue per day. His wife is a farmer and earns less than $1 a day. They have three children, two of whom are in school and one who is too young to attend.

Nhor S. would like to take out a loan to purchase steel and other materials.

loans.use: To purchase steel and other materials

loans.name: Um

texts.en: Um T., pictured here with her oldest daughter, is 55 years old. She has a business selling rice noodles and porridge from her home to earn approximately $15 in revenue per day. Her husband and two of her children are chicken sellers at the market. On average, they typically make $100 every day in revenue. Um T. is asking for a loan to purchase chickens and ducks to sell at the market.

loans.use: Buy chickens and ducks

loans.name: Luong

texts.vi:
Chị Đàm Thị Lương năm nay 43 tuổi, chị là thành viên Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1998. Hiện tại cả hai vợ chồng chị đều làm nghề chăn nuôi lợn, gà  và trồng trọt tại xã Phù Linh huyện Sóc Sơn - Hà Nội. Với mức thu nhập 2.500.000đ chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia đình chị dang ngày càng có thêm điều kiện để cải thiện cuộc sống
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn mua thêm lợn về nuôi.
texts.en:
Ms. Đàm Thị Lương is 43 yrs old, and has been a member of TYM fund since 1998. Presently both she and her husband raise pigs, chickens and vegetable farming in the village of Phù Linh in the district of Sóc Sơn in Hà Nội. With income of 145 USD from raising animals, her family meets the conditions necessary to improve their lives. For her next loan, she wishes to borrow 575 USD to purchase additional pigs to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising animals

loans.name: Vinh

texts.vi:
Chị Đinh Thị Vinh 52  tuổi, gia đình chị có 4 con trong đó có 1 con đang đi học. năm 2003 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Đến nay sau 5 năm sử dụng vốn vay hiệu quả mô hình chăn nuôi của gia đình chị đang ngày càng được mở rộng hơn với việc chăn nuôi bò và gà thịt. Ngoài thu nhập từ chăn nuôi hàng tháng gia đình chị còn có thêm nguồn thu ổn định từ lương của chị nên kinh tế khá ổn định với mức thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn mua 1 con bò và gà giống về nuôi.
texts.en:
Ms. Đinh Thị Vinh is 52 yrs old.Her family consists of 4 children with 1 still in school. In 2003 she joined TYM fund to borrow money to invest in raising animals. After 5 years of being in the fund, her family's business has expanded to raising cows and chickens. In addition to raising animals, she also has a stable source of income from her own salary so her family's income is stable at 172 USD/month. For her next loan, she wishes to borrow 575 USD to purchase 1 additional cow and chickens to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: raising animals

loans.name: Say

texts.en: Say L., 51, is a mother of five children and resides in Takeo, Cambodia. To earn a living, she sells vegetables at the market and earns approximately $50 in revenue per day. Her husband is a carpenter and makes $2.50 of profit a day. All of their children are employed as garment-factory workers and sellers. Mrs. Say L. would like to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike to resell it.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to resell

loans.name: Thieu

texts.vi:
Chị Đàm Thị Thiều 61 tuổi, là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1996. Chị đang sống cùng chồng  là cán bộ hưu trí và 1 con đã trưởng thành. Hiện tại công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị là từ kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá và lương hưu của chồng với thu nhập 4.500.000đ/ tháng
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư cho công việc kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá của gia đình.
texts.en:
Ms. Đàm Thị Thiều is 61 yrs old, and has been a member of TYM fund since 1996. She lives with her husband, who is a retired soldier, and 1 grown child. Presently the main source of their income is from their grocery store and her husband's retirement pension, totaling 258 USD per month. For her next loan, she wishes to borrow 575 USD to invest in her grocery store.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Ty

texts.en: Ty B., 51, is a widow and lives with her daughter in Takeo province. She has been a teacher since 1984, and is able to make US$2.50 per day. Her daughter stays at home and sells grocery items and makes US$20 in revenue. Ty B. would like to take out a loan to expand the grocery store by adding more products to meet customer demand.

loans.use: To expand grocery store.

loans.name: Lien

texts.vi:
Chị Dương Thị Liên 69 tuổi, gia đình chị có  4 con đều đã trưởng thành.  Năm 1994 chị tham gia vào Quỹ vay  vốn để đầu tư buốn bán đồ nhựa và hàng tạp hoá. Hiện tại chị đã  mua được quầy hàng cố định tại chợ huyện Sóc Sơn- Hà Nội. Hàng tháng bên cạnh nguồn thu từ kinh doanh gia đình chị còn có thêm thu nhập từ lương hưu của chồng với thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư cho công việc kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá của gia đình.
texts.en:
Ms. Dương Thị Liên is 69 yrs old. She has 4 children who are all grown. In 1994 she joined TYM fund to borrow money to invest in a business selling plastic merchandise and grocery. Presently she has a kiosk at the market in the district of Sóc Sơn in Hà Nội. In addition to her income from the grocery business, she also has another source of income from her husband's retirement pension, totaling 288 USD per month. For her next loan, she wishes to borrow 575 USD to invest in her grocery business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Bình 36  tuổi, chị đang sống cùng chồng và hai con đang đi học tại xã Tiên Dược huyện Sóc Sơn - Hà Nội. Năm 1999 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá . Hiện  tại công việc kinh doanh của gia đình chị đang phát triển khá thuận lợi và đem lại cho gia đình chị thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Bình, 36 years old, lives with her husband and two children who attend school in Tiên Dược commune, Sóc Sơn district, Hà Nội. In 1999, she became a member of the TYM Fund and used a loan to open a small grocery shop. Currently, this family business is doing rather well and provides them with a monthly income of 5,000,000 VND (288 USD). In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND (575 USD) to invest in their business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grocery shop

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Hoà  27  tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm2007. Hiện tại chị đang chăn nuôi lợn , trồng lúa, rau tại nhà. Ngoài thời gian chăn nuôi, trồng trọt chị còn đi làm thuê cho cửa hàng chuyên kinh doanh dịch vụ ăn uống tại địa phương để tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Với mức thu nhập 2.500.000đ/ tháng, cuộc sống của gia đình chị đang ngày càng được cải thiện hơn.Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm lợn và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Hoà, 27 years old, has participated in the TYM Fund since 2007. Currently, she raises pigs and grows rice and vegetables at her home. Outside the time she spends on her animals and farming, she works part-time as a waitress in a local restaurant in order to earn some extra income for her family. With an income of 2,500,000 VND (144 USD) per month, the standard of living of her family is now steadily improving. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND (575 USD) to buy more pigs and animal feed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Phạm Thị Hải 49 tuổi, chị là thành viên Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1995. Trước khi tham gia Quỹ tình thương kinh tế gia đình chị rất khó khăn do thu nhập chủ yếu dựa vào chăn nuôi, trồng trọt. Sau khi tham gia Quỹ, nhờ có thêm nguồn vốn chị đã đầu tư mở rộng chăn nuôi  và mua đồ nấu rượu bán. Hiện tại đây cũng là những công việc đem lại nguồn thu  chính cho gia đình  chị với thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Ngoài thời gian phụ giúp vợ trong công việc chăn nuôi, để tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình anh Minh chồng chị còn làm thêm nghề xe ôm cho thu nhập 1.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn mua thêm lợn về nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Phạm Thị Hải, 49 years old, has been a member of the TYM Fund since 1995. Before she joined the Fund, the financial situation of her family was very difficult because their income depended solely on raising animals and farming. When she joined the Fund, she used this source of capital to expand her activities raising animals and to buy equipment for brewing wine. Now, these are the main sources of income for her family, providing them with income of 2,000,000 VND (117 USD) per month. Besides helping Hải with the animals, her husband Minh works as a motorbike taxi driver to earn an extra 1,000,000 VND (58 USD) per month for the family. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 15,000,000 VND (875 USD) to buy more pigs to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Sharofat

texts.en:
K. Sharofat is 40 years old. She’s married with four children. The difficult circumstances and hardships in her life made her recognize the value of work from a very young age. For about 11 years she has been purchasing young sheep and calves in the local market, fattening them and then selling them.

Sharofat is a very hard-working woman, and her diligence is incredible. She works with a strength worthy of immense admiration. She has always looked for a way to provide extra income to her household. Sharofat wakes up early every morning to feed her cows and bulls, with the goal of fattening them and selling them at the best price in the local market.

Thanks to this activity she is supporting her children with education. Sharofat wants to keep educating them because she hopes that they’ll reach the goals that they have laid out for themselves.

With this purpose in mind, she is requesting a loan of $750 to buy calves in order to expand her business. Let’s support this brave woman who has a lot of courage and strength to live.

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and being the location of the end of the rule of Alexander the Great. It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country, filled with epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and boasts a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only 7 percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: Purchasing small cattle in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family

loans.name: My

texts.en: My S., 28, pictured here with her husband, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo, Cambodia. To earn a living, she and her husband stay at home making rice wine and are able to make US$6 per day. This couple has three children, two of whom are in school and one is too young to attend. They would like to take out a loan to purchase rice so that they can make more wine to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase rice.

loans.name: Buy

texts.en: Buy S., 31, resides in Bati district, Takeo province, with her husband and two of her young children. She and her husband have a business selling fish at the market and are able to make US$50 in revenue. This business has been around for five years. Buy S. would like to take out a loan to purchase more fish to sell at the market. (She is pictured with her husband.)

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Văn 45 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2002. Hiện gia đình chị đang kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá và sản xuất công cụ lao động thủ công ( Liềm, dao, cuốc..) tại nhà. Đây cũng là những công việc đem lại cho gia đình chị nguồn thu nhập ổn định 3.500.000/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ một phần chị sử dụng để mua sắt về sản xuất liềm, dao bán, phần còn lại chị sử dụng để đầu tư kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Văn, 45 years old, has participated in the TYM Fund since 2002. Currently, her family operates two businesses from their home – selling groceries and producing hand-crafted tools for manual labor such as sickles, knives, and hoes. Together these businesses provide the family with a steady income of 3,500,000 VND (200 USD) per month. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND (575 USD), one part to be used to buy iron to produce sickles and hoes for sale, and the rest she will invest in her grocery shop.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Manufacturing hand tools, selling groceries

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo Y., 49, is a widow who lives with her two children in Takeo, Cambodia. She works in a grocery store, making about US$4 every day. Both of her children are employed. Keo Y. is asking for a loan to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work. This motorbike will also be used to transport grocery items from market to sell at home.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Thơm 33 tuổi, chị là thành viên Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2004. Trước khi tham gia Quỹ tình thương kinh tế gia đình chị rất khó khăn do thu nhập chủ yếu dựa vào chăn nuôi, trồng trọt. Sau khi tham gia Quỹ, nhờ có thêm nguồn vốn chị đã đầu tư để buôn bán phế liệu. Hiện tại  chăn nuôi và buôn bán phế liệu là những công việc đem lại nguồn thu chính cho gia đình chị với thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng. 
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn đi thu mua phế liệu.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Thơm, 33 years old, has been a member of the TYM Fund since 2004. Before she joined the TYM Fund, the financial situation of her family was very difficult because their income depended solely on raising animals and farming. When she joined the Fund, it provided her with capital to invest in a business selling scrap materials. Currently, raising animals and her scrap materials business are the main sources of income for her family, for a total of 4,000,000 VND (230 USD) per month. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND (575 USD) to invest in buying up scrap materials for her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Scrap materials business

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Chúc 33 tuổi, gia đình chị có hai con còn nhỏ. Chị là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ đầu năm 2008.  Hiện tại hai vợ chồng chị  Chúc đang làm nghề thu mua phế liệu và buôn bán hoa quả. Đây cũng là những công việc đem lại nguồn thu  chính cho gia đình chị với thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn cho công việc thu mua phế liệu và buôn bán hoa quả của gia
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Chúc, 33 years old, has two young children. She has been a member of the TYM Fund since the beginning of 2008. Currently, Mrs. Chúc and her husband work together selling recyclable scrap materials and also selling fruit. These two activities are the family’s main sources of income, earning them 5,000,000 VND (292 USD) per month. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 9,000,000 VND (525 USD) to invest in both the scrap materials and the fruit selling enterprises of the family.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Scrap materials and Fruit selling

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: Pich S., 46, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province, Cambodia. Since 2004, she has been selling bananas and is able to make US$6 per day. Her husband, pictured here, is a motor-taxi driver and makes US$5 per day. This couple has six children, five of whom are in school and one who is too young to attend. Mrs. Pich S. is asking for a loan to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business.

loans.use: To operate a motor-taxi business.

loans.name: Ngo Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Ngô Thị Hiền năm nay 42 tuổi .Năm 1997 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn. Đến nay sau hơn 10 năm tham gia Quỹ gia đình chị đã tích luỹ thêm vốn để đầu tư vào dịch vụ điện nước phục vụ nhu cầu của bà con nông thôn.  Anh Hùng chồng chị là cán bộ hưu trí hiện đang làm thêm công tác xã hội tại thôn Với thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng kinh tế gia đình chị Hiền đang ngày càng ổn định và có thêm điều kiện để đầu tư cho con đi học đại học.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư cho chăn nuôi và mua thêm thiết bị phục vụ cho công việc kinh doanh dịch vụ điện nước của gia đình
texts.en:
Ms. Ngô Thị Hiền is 42 years old. In 1997, she joined TYM Fund and borrowed capital to invest in rearing pigs. Today, after more than ten years of participation in the fund, her family has accumulated a financial reserve to invest towards a utilities (electricity and plumbing) business services the needs of the community. Mr. Hùng, her husband, is a retired government employee who is currently active in social programs for their local community. With an income of 5,000,000 VND per month, Ms. Hiền's family's financial situation continues to improve each day and allows them to make plans for their children to attend high school. For the upcoming loan cycle, she hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND to put towards rearing livestock and materials for their electricity/plumbing business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising Livestock; Electricity/Plumbing Business

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị T. 46 tuổi. Năm 1996 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Qua 13 năm tham gia vay vốn và đầu tư hiệu quả hiện nay công việc chăn nuôi của gia đình chị đang ngày càng được mở rộng và và phát triển. Với mức thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng từ chăn nuôi gia đình chị T. đang ngày càng có thêm điều kiện để cải thiện cuộc sống.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu mua gà thịt và cá về nuôi.
texts.en:
Ms. Nguyễn Thị T. is 46 years old. In 1996 she joined TYM Fund and borrowed to put towards raising livestock. After 13 years of participation in the fund and getting good investment results, her family's livestock rearing activities continues to grow and evolve. With an income of 5,000,000 VND per month from raising livestock, Ms. T.'s family is more able to improve their livelihood with each day that passes. For the upcoming loan cycle, she hopes to borrow 15,000,000 VND to purchase chicken, ducks, and fish to rear.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising Livestock

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Thuận năm nay 42 tuổi, chị đang sống cùng chồng và 1 con tại xã Trung Giã huyện Sóc Sơn  Hà Nội. Chị Thuận là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1995. Hiện tại công việc đem lại nguồn thu chính cho gia đinhf chị Thuận là từ chăn nuôi, buôn bán rau và lương thợ xây của chồng với thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn cho công việc buôn bán rau của gia đình.
texts.en:
Ms. Nguyễn Thị Thuận is 42 years old. She is living with her husband and one child in Trung Giã village, Sóc Sơn district, Hà Nội. Ms. Thuận has been a participant of TYM Fund since 1995. Currently, the main sources of income for the family are rearing livestock, buying/selling vegetables and Ms. Thuận's husband's salary as a construction worker. They have an income of 4,000,000 VND per month. This loan cycle she hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND to invest in the family's vegetable retailing business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Selling Vegetables

loans.name: Sai Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Sái Thị V. năm nay 45 tuổi, chị đang sống cùng chồng và 2 con đang đi học  tại xã Tân Hưng huyện Sóc Sơn  Hà Nội. Chị V. là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1996. Hiện tại hai vợ chồng chị V. đều đang chăn nuôi lợn, vịt, cá tại gia đình. Đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu chính cho gia đình chị với thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để đầu tư cốn mua thức ăn phục vụ cho công việc chăn nuôi của gia đình.
texts.en:
Ms. Sái Thị V. is 45 years old. She is living with her husband and two school-aged children in Tân Hưng village, Sóc Sơn district, Hà Nội. Ms. V. has been a patron of TYM Fund since 1996. Today, the couple are raising pigs, ducks, and fish. This is also the family's main source of income providing 5,000,000 VND per month. For the upcoming loan cycle, she hopes to borrow 20,000,000 VND to purchase animal feed for their livestock rearing activities.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase animal feed for rearing livestock

loans.name: Hiyam

texts.en:
Hiyam is a 43-year-old woman who lives in Bourj el Barajneh, southern suburbs of Lebanon, with her husband and their four children. Hiyam has owned a bakery since 2003. She has a saj oven in which she does mankoucheh or markouk. The saj is the metal oven where you make the saj bread, a traditional Lebanese cooking dome used to make Markouk (thinned) bread, doughy confections or mankoucheh. A mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza and its most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it any time of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning.

Hiyam requested a loan of $1,000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw materials for her work and change the décor of her bakery. This is the first time that Hiyam has requested a loan.

Hiyam is special in her work because she does it well and she is also the only one who does it in her neighborhood. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she was lucky to not have any difficulties. Hiyam decided on doing her business because her mankoucheh is good and plus, she always wanted to open a bakery. In the future, she plans on improving her business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and change the décor of her bakery

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Trần Thị L.  46 tuổi, chị là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1995. Hiện tại cả hai vợ chồng chị đều chăn nuôi lợn và đấu thầu ao nuôi cá. Đây cũng là công việc đem lại cho gia đình chị thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu mua thêm lợn và cá giống về nuôi.
texts.en:
Ms. Trần Thị L. is 46 years old. She has been a participant of TYM Fund since 1995. Currently, she and her husband are raising pigs and bidding for a pond partition to raise fish. These are also the main sources of income for their family providing an income of 5,000,000 VND per month. For the upcoming loan cycle, she hopes to raise 15,000,000 VND to purchase more pigs and fish to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising Pigs and Fish

loans.name: Houda

texts.en:
Houda is a 35-year-old divorced woman who lives in Bourj el Barajneh with her daughter. Houda has been doing tattoos since 2002, and has been doing eyebrows for a year. Houda requested a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for her tattoos. This is her fourth loan cycle and she has always paid on time. 

Her previous loans helped her purchase what she needed for her work, and with them she was able to meet her family’s needs. Houda is a specialist in her work because she does it well. Her clients are her friends, neighbors and others. Houda decided to start her business after she got divorced, because she had to depend on herself. In the future, she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase tools for her tattoo business.

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Van N., 52, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo province, Cambodia. She grows and sells rice to earn a living and is able to make US$4 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver and typically makes US$3 every day. Van N. wants to take out a loan of US$500 to make a new investment. She will purchase mangos and sell them to the market to make additional profits.

loans.use: Purchase and sell mangos.

loans.name: Ni Ketut Suwardi

texts.id:
Usia yang semakin tua tak menghalangi Ni Ketut Suwardi untuk selalu tetap bersemangat dalam mengembangkan usaha ternak babi. Apalagi melihat peluang keuntungan yang akan di dapatnya, menambah motivasinya menjadi lebih optimis dalam menjalani usaha ini.satu tahun telah berjalan , keuntungan yang didapat pun semakin membaik .Jika  6 bulan sebelumnya Ni Ketut Suwardi Di perhadapkan dengan persoalan kenaikan harga pakan , kini tak begitu masalah karena telah di imbangi dengan kenaiakn harga Babi. Panen Terakhir  Ni Ketut Suwardi mendapat Rp750.000 keuntungan bersih dari 2 ekor babi peliharaanya , Dan Kedepannya Ni Kt Suwardi Berencana untuk Membeli satu Ekor induk babi sehingga tidak perlu lagi membeli bibit untuk di gemukkan . 
 Untuk mendukung rencananya itu Ni Ketut Suwardi masih sangat memerlukan pinjaman modal dari Dinari ,karena semua keuntungan yang di dapat telah  di pergunakanNya  untuk membantu biaya pendidikan 3 orang anaknya.kare hasil yang di dapat oleh suaminya yang bekerja sebagai seorang petanibelum bisa mencukupi. 
Dengan mengembangkan usaha ternak ini harapan Ni Ketut Suwardi untuk dapat mewujudkan impiannya menyekolahkan anak bungsunya sampai ketingkat yang lebih tinggi.
texts.en:
Old age does not diminish Ni Ketut Suwardi's motivation in farming her pigs. She sees a lot of profit potential in this business. She also managed to improve the profitability of her farm. 6 Months ago, Ni Ketut Suwardi was worried about rising feed prices, however it is no longer a problem as pork prices also increased. Last slaughter season, Ni Ketut Suwardi managed to earn net profit of $70 for her 2 pigs. She plans to purchase one breeding pig, so she does not to purchase her piglets anymore. To support her plan, Ni Ketut Suwardi needs funding help from DInari, as she used the profits from last harvest was used to pay for her 3 children's tuitions. Her husband works as a contract farmer with uncertain income stream. She hopes that she can pay for her eldest child higher education with profits from her farm.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy piglets and feed

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Phan Thị Thuỷ  34 tuổi, chị là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2000. Hiện tại chị Thuỷ đang chăn nuôi tại nhà và đi thu mua phế liệu còn anh Khải chồng chị làm dịch vụ xây dựng. Với mức thu nhập 3.500.000đ/ tháng gia đình chị Thuỷ đang ngày càng có thêm điều kiện để cải thiện cuộc sống và đầu tư cho 3 con đi học.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu mua 10 con lợn và thức ăn về chăn nuôi, số vốn còn lại chị sử dụng để đầu tư đi thu mua phế liệu.
texts.en:
Ms. Phan Thị Thuỷ is 34 years old. She has been a participant of TYM Fund since 2000. Currently, Ms. Thuỷ is raising livestock and gathering/buying scrap (metal); while Mr. Khải, her husband, works in construction. With an income of 3,500,000 VND per month, Ms. Thuỷ's family continues to develop their ability to improve their lifestyle and put money towards providing the three children with an education. For this upcoming loan cycle, she hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND to purchase ten pigs and animal feed; any remaining funds will be used to gather/buy scrap (metal).

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Pigs and Animal Feed; Put towards business

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 45-year-old man who lives in Bourj el Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon with his wife and their six children. Hassan has owned a grocery store since 1979. He is requesting a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his store. This is his third loan cycle and he has always paid on time. 

His previous loans helped him purchase merchandise and diversify his stock. Hassan is successful in his work because he is known in the region and everyone likes buying from him. His clients are his friends and neighbors. Hassan took over this business from his father. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Hassane

texts.en:
Hassane is a 32-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh in southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Hassane has been working as a furniture painter for several years. He requested a loan of $1100 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase paint and tools for his business. This is his second loan cycle and he has always paid on time. 

His previous loan helped him expand his business. Hassane is successful because he completes the work on time and does it well. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Hassane first started his business, he didn’t have the start up capital. He decided to open his business because of his experience, and he wanted to work independently. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase paint and tools

loans.name: Chheng

texts.en: ChH. H., 50, is a security man and carpenter in Takeo province. He is married with five children, three are in school and two are employed, and his wife, pictured here, sells desserts. She typically makes about US$4 each day. In order to increase family profits, he is asking for US$800 to purchase a sawing machine and wood.

loans.use: To purchase sawing machine and wood.

loans.name: Mouhamad

texts.en: Mouhamad is a 45-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, Southern Lebanon with his wife. Mouhamad has been working in agriculture for ten years. He plants different type of vegetables. He requested a loan of $1,000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is the first time that Mouhamad has requested a loan.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work.

loans.name: Zaki

texts.en:
Zaki is a 57-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, southern Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Zaki has owned a mini-market for ten years. He requested a loan of $900 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his market. Zaki has been a micro credit client for six years now and has always paid on time. 
His previous loans helped him improve his business and his financial situation. Zaki is special in his work because he has diverse merchandise. In the future, he plans to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his market.

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en:
BilA. is a 23-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, Southern Lebanon with his wife and their child. BilA. has been working as a car painter for a year and a half. He requested a loan of $1000 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase tools and paint for his work. This is the first time that BilA. has requested a loan.

BilA. is speciA. in his work because he does it well. His clients can be anybody. When he first started his business, he didn’t face any difficulty. BilA. decided on doing his business because he wanted to improve his family’s income. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools and paint for his work.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his business

loans.name: Chama

texts.en:
Chama is a 48-year-old woman who lives in Tyre, Southern Lebanon with her husband and their four children. Chama has owned a bakery for 13 years. She makes “mankoucheh”. A mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza; most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. Chama requested a loan of $500 US dollars from Al Majmoua to purchase raw materials for her business like cheese, flour, and oil. Chama has been a micro credit client for five years now and has always paid on time.

Her previous loans helped her improve her bakery and increase her income. Chama is special in her work because she does it well and her mankoucheh are known for their good taste. Her clients can be anybody. Chama decided on this business because she wanted to supplement her family’s income. In the future, she plans to purchase a car.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for her business.

loans.name: Ni Made Karti

texts.id:
Ni Made Karti tinggal di sebuah dusun yang bernama Dusun Katulampa, Manistutu. Ni Made Karti tinggal bersama suaminya I Ketut Derken dan seorang anak laki – lakinya bernama I Gede Indra Purnawan. Rumah yang ditempatinya adalah rumah sendiri. Namun tanahnya merupakan tanah keluaraga. I Ketut Derken suaminya, bekerja sebagai petani. Penghasilan suaminya ini hanya cukup untuk biaya hidup sehari – hari. Sedangkan untuk biaya sekolah anaknya yang baru duduk di kelas 1 SD masih belum terpenuhi. Untuk itu Ni Made Karti memelihara babi untuk menambah penghasilan keluarganya. Saat ini Ni Made Karti sudah memelihara 2 ekor induk babi, 1 pejantan dan 8 ekor penggemukan. Dalam waktu 6 bulan, Ni Made Karti bisa menghabiskan dana sebesar ± Rp. 500.000,- untuk membeli pakan ternak babinya. Ni Made Karti mengalami kekurangan dana untuk membeli pakan ternak babinya tersebut. 
 Untuk mendukung usahanya itu Ni Made Karti sangat memerlukan pinjaman modal dari Dinari. Ni made Karti mengikuti program pinjaman Dinari dengan jangka waktu 6 bulan yang pembayarannya dilakukan di akhir periode. Dengan mengikuti program ini, Ni Made Karti berharap usahanya bisa berkembang dan cita – citanya untuk  menyekolahkan anaknya ketingkat yang lebih tinggi dapat terwujud, serta penghasilan rumah tangganya dapat meningkat.
texts.en:
Ni Made Karti lives in "Katulampa" village with her husband, I Ketut Derken and her son, I Gede Indra Purnawan. She lives in her own home, not a rental, but the land is owned collectively by her family. I Ketut Derken, Ni Made Karti's husband works as a farmer. Her husband's income is barely sufficient to pay for daily expenses. She still needs additional income to pay for her son's grade school tuition. So she started to farm pigs to supplement her family's income. Currently, Ni made Karti owns 2 breeding pigs, one male and 8 fattening pigs. In 6 months, Ni Made Karti spends about $40 to purchase feeds for her pigs. So to pay for her business' daily expense, she required DINARI's help. Ni Made Karti applied for 6 month loan program from DInari. Through this program, Ni Made Karti hopes that her business can grow and her dream that her son finish all his education can come true and her household income can improve.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy feeds

loans.name: Maurene

texts.en:
Maurene D. raises pigs. She is 30 years old and has 6 loving children. She has raised pigs for 13 years now. Her husband is a farmer and tills the land to support their family. Aside from pigs, she grows vegetables in their backyard. The harvest is what she uses to provide for their other needs. Maurene's income from her pig business greatly helps her family to pay for school fees and books. 

She is asking for a loan of PHP8,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy piglets and feed for the pigs. The loan will truly help her develop her business more and have more piglets.

CEVI is a non-profit organization and a partner of WorldVision Philippines that helps people start and have their own businesses. They not only provide credit, but also training and insurance coverage to help their clients' businesses develop.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and sacks of feed.

loans.name: Ni Made Suderti

texts.id:
Namanya Ni Made Suderti. Dia tinggal di sebuah rumah yang sederhana, di Dusun Katulampa,  Desa Manistutu. Suaminya I Made Tinggal bekerja sebagai petani. Mereka mempunyai 2 orang anak. Yang pertama, laki – laki bernama Putu Mei Sudiantara, sudah kelas 2 SMA. Sedangkan yang kedua, perempuan bernama Ni Luh Kadek Febrianti, baru kelas 2 SD.
Pekerjaan suami Ni Made Suderti yang hanya seorang petani, belum mencukupi kebutuhan rumah tangganya. Padahal Dia juga masih harus membiayai kedua anaknya yang masih bersekolah. Di jaman seperti sekarang ini, biaya sekolah tidaklah murah. Untuk itu Ni Made Suderti memilih memelihara 1 ekor induk babi dan 2 ekor penggemukan. Namun Ni Made Suderti tidak mempunyai cukup dana untuk membeli pakan ternak untuk babinya tersebut. Karena dalam 6 bulan, Ni Made Suderti bisa menghabiskan biaya ± Rp. 500.000,- untuk 1 ekor babi.
Ni Made Suderti mengajukan pinjaman modal ke Dinari, dengan program 6 bulan dan dibayar di akhir periode. Dengan pinjaman ini, Ni Made Suderti berencana menggunakannya untuk membeli pakan untuk ternak babinya. Ni Made Suderti berharap setelah mendapat pinjaman modal ini, usahanya memelihara babi dapat berkembang. Sehingga Dia dapat membantu suaminya memenuhi biaya sekolah anaknya, serta kehidupan rumah tangganya dapat pula meningkat.
texts.en:
Ni Made Suderti lives in a simple house in Katulampa village in manistutu region. Her husband, I Made works as a farmer. They has 2 children. The eldest sone, Putu Mei Sudiantara is studying at 2nd grade of high school, and the second daughter, Ni Luh Kadek Febrianti is studying in 2nd grade of primary school. Ni Made Suderti is a farmer with insufficient income to pay for all her family expenses. Her husband's income is not sufficient to pay for her children's tuitions. Currently school tuitions are not cheap. To supplement her family's income, Ni Made Suderti started farming 1 breeding pig and 2 fattening pigs. However she did not have enough money to purchase feeds. In 6 months, Ni Made Suderti spends about $40 per pigs. Ni Made Suderti is applying for a 6 month loan to DInari to purchase feeds for her farmed pigs. With this loan, she hopes to grow her business and help her husband to pay for her children's tuition with the profit.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy feeds

loans.name: Ni Komang Wandi

texts.id:
Supaya dapat menambah penghasilan keluarga, Ni Komang Wandi mempunyai usaha beternak babi. Dia memelihara 1 ekor induk dan 3 ekor penggemukan. Dalam usahanya memelihara babi, Ni Komang Wandi bisa menghabiskan  ± 500.000,- dalam waktu 6 bulan untuk membeli pakan ternak babi. Namun dalam situasi ekonomi keluarganya yang masih minim, Ni Komang Wandi belum bisa memenuhi dana yang di butuhkan untuk ternak babinya tersebut. Karena suaminya I Nengah Winada hanya bekerja sebagai petani. Penghasilan suaminya hanya cukup untuk memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangganya saja. Ni Komang Wandi mempunyai seorang anak laki – laki bernama I Gede Lingguarta. Ni Komang Wandi dan keluarganya tinggal di sebuah rumah sederhana yang tanahnya masih ikut menumpang dengah orang lain di Dusun Katulampa, Desa Manistutu.
Karena biaya sekolah sangat tinggi, Ni komang Wandi tidak dapat memenuhi biaya sekolah  anaknya. Sehingga kini anaknya putus sekolah. Ni Komang Wandi, sangat berharap anaknya bisa sekolah.
 Oleh karena itu Ni Komang Wandi sangat antusias untuk mengikuti program ternak babi yang ada di Dinari. Dimana program ini meminjamkan modal bagi peternak babi dengan jangka waktu 6 bulan dan dibayar diakhir periode.
