Dengan harapan setelah mendapat pinjaman modal dari Dinari, Ni Komang Wandi dapat membeli pakan untuk ternak babinya. Sehingga usaha ternak babinya dapat berkembang dan Ni Komang Wandi dapat menyekolahkan kembali anaknya.
texts.en:
Ni Komang Wandi owns a pig farm to supplement her family's income. She farms 1 breeder and 3 fattening pigs. Ni Komang Wandi can spend up to $40 every 6 months per pigs for feeds. However with her family's difficult economic situation, Ni Komang Wandi does not have sufficient funds to operate her pig farm to its full potential. Her husband, I Nengah Winada works as a farmer with barely sufficient income to pay for their family's expenses Ni komang Wandi has a son named I Gede Lingguarta. Ni Komang Wandi and her family owns a simple home, but it liens on someone else's land in Katulampa Village, Manistutu Regency. Ni Komang Wandi cannot pay for her son's schooling due to the high tuition cost. Therefore currently her son is not attending school anymore. Ni Komang Wandi really hopes she can send her son back to school. Therefore, Ni Komang Wandi is really enthusiastic to join DInari's pig farm program. This program provides 6 month loan and technical assistance. Ni Komang Wardi is hopeful with the loan she can purchase more feeds for the farm, so her pig farm can grow so she can afford tuition for her son again.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy feeds

loans.name: Bella

texts.en:
Bella S. owns a small piggery. She is 32 years old and has 7 children. She has been in the hog raising business for 12 years now. From her business, she was able to pay for her family's needs as well as the tuition, books and miscellaneous fees of the schools. Her husband is a farmer. He grows rice to feed and clothe his family. Bella knows that they have to work hard for their family. She wants to have all her children graduate from college to be able to find better jobs in the future to support their future families. 

She is asking for a loan of PHP15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy 6 piglets and 7 sacks of feed. Some of the loan will go to her children's education. The loan will definitely help Bella expand her pig business and start a new one for additional income.

CEVI is a non-profit organization and a partner of WorldVision Philippines that helps people start and have their own business. They provide not only credit but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase 6 piglets and 7 sacks of feed.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Lành năm nay 34 tuổi, chị là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1999.  Hiện tại chị Lành bán đồ ăn sáng tại chợ và chăn nuôi lợn, cá tại nhà còn chồng chị làm nghề thợ xây. Đây cũng là những công việc đem lại cho gia đình chị thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để đầu tư mua nguyên vật liệu kè lại ao và mua cá về nuôi.
texts.en:
Nguyễn Thị Lành is 34 years old. She is a TYM fund member since 1999. Currently she sells breakfast at the market in the morning. She also raises pigs & farms fish. Her husband is a construction worker. These are the income source for her family which is 4.000.000 VND a month. For this round, she is requesting a loan of 20.000.000 VND to rebuild the fish pond and buy fishes.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to rebuild fish pond and buy fishes

loans.name: Ngo Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Ngô Thị Tấc năm nay 47 tuổi, gia đình chị có 3 người con trong đó có 1 con đang đi lao động xuất khẩu. Chị Tấc là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1995. Hiện tại thu nhập chính của gia đình chị là từ chăn nuôi và sự hỗ trợ của người con đã đi làm. Với việc chăn nuôi lợn con và 25 con lợn thịt thu nhập của gia đình chị đạt 4.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm lợn và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Ngô Thị Tấc is 47 years old. She has 3 children, one of which is working oversea. She is a TYM fund member since 1995. Currently her family income sources are from raising pigs and contribution from her son who's working oversea. She raises piglets and another 25 pigs for meat. Her family income is 4.000.000 VND a month. This round of loan, she wishes to borrow 20.000.000 VND to buy more piglets and feed for the animals.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy piglets and feed

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Mơ   năm nay 52 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1998. Thời gian đầu chị Thảnh vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn, đến nay sau 10 năm tham gia Quỹ gia đình chị đã có thêm vốn để đầu tư mở rộng mô hình chăn nuôi. Hiện nay gia đình chị đang chủ yếu đầu tư chăn nuôi bò sinh sản  mỗi năm gia đình chị được lãi khoảng 20triệu từ việc chăn nuôi bò.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm 2 con bò và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Nguyễn Thị Mơ is 52 years old. She is a TYM fund member since 1998. In the beginning she invested her money in pig raising business. Now 10 years later, she has expanded her operation. Her family now breeds cows, the yearly profit from this business is 20.000.000 VND. This round she is requesting a loan of 15.000.000 VND to buy 2 cows and food for the animals.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy 2 cows and animal food

loans.name: Houv

texts.en:
H. is 50 years old and a resident of Siem Reap Province. He is the father of three children: all of them are married and live separately. He is married to Rom, 51, who earns a living planting vegetables behind her house. H. owns an old small tri-wheel cart for his firewood service to the whole commune and he has been in this business for more than two years. He travels far for his sales and he gains a lot of customers.

H. also owns a plot of farmland which he inherited from his parents. Recently, H. is preparing for his paddy field; he is tired of having to hire his neighbor's oxen for his family since he doesn't have any ox. To help reduce the family's expenses, H. is taking a loan of US$ 300 to buy a pair of buffalo for plowing the farmland. He dreams of having a big house for his family.

loans.use: To buy a pair of buffalo for plowing the farmland

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Liệu năm nay 47tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1999. Hiện tại chị đang kinh doanh cửa hàng ăn tại nhà còn chồng chị làm nghề xe ôm. Công việc kinh doanh ngày càng ổn định đem lại cho gia đình chị thu nhập 2.500.000đ/ tháng
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thực phẩm về đầu tư vào cửa hàng ăn
texts.en:
Nguyễn Thị Liệu is 47 years old. She is a TYM fund member since 1999. Currently she runs a restaurant right in her house. Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver. Her family income is quite stable, 2.500.000 VND a month. For this round of loan, she wishes to borrow 15.000.000 VND to buy food products for her restaurant

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy food products for her restaurant

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Trần Thị L.  năm nay  57 tuổi, chị là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2006. Chồng chị không may mất sớm, hiện chị đang sống cùng 1 con đã trưởng thành. Với việc chăn nuôi 30 con lợn và sự hỗ trợ thêm của con hàng thánh thu nhập của gia đình chị đạt 2.000.000
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua 20 con lợn nái về nuôi.
texts.en:
Trần Thị L. is 57 years old, a TYM fund member since 2006. Her husband has passed away. She is living with her adult child. She raises 30 pigs. Her income is 2.000.000 VND including the contribution from her adult child. For this round of L. she wishes to borrow 9.000.000 VND to buy 20 sows to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy 20 sows

loans.name: Vasil

texts.en:
Vasil is married. He owns a retail business in Belaya Tserkov and sells various home products at the local market. He has been in this business for 16 years already. He tried selling various types of products and finally setled on this one. Vasil is a hard-working and persistent person. These character traits have helped him to develop his business and make it a stable source of income.

Vasil would like to get a loan of 5,000 UAH to increase his inventory and offer his customers an even bigger variety of goods. His business goal is to make enough money to help his children and grandchildren as well as fix up his property and plant a nice fruit garden.

loans.use: to increase the inventory of  his shop

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Chiên  năm nay 44  tuổi, chị là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2006. Gia đình  chị có 3 con trong đó có hai con đang tuổi đến trường. Hiện tại chị ở nhà chăn nuôi lợn còn chồng chị đi đóng gạch thuê. Ngoài ra con trai chị đã có công ăn việc làm ổn định hàng tháng đều hỗ trợ thêm cho gia đình. Với thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng kinh tế gia đình chi đang ngày càng ổn định hơn.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư mua lợn và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Nguyễn Thị Chiên is 44 years old, a TYM fund member since 2006. She has 3 children, 2 of which are still in school. She raises pigs at home and her husband is a brick layer. Their son holds a steady job and contributes to the family income which is stable at 2.000.000 VND a month. For this round of loan she is requesting 10.000.000 to buy pis to raise and food for the animals.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy pigs and food for animals

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian D. owns a small farm. She grows rice and vegetables. Her husband, George D., is also a farmer. Together, they till the land to support the growing needs of their family. She started her farm business in 2000. She manages 1 hectare of land by using the small savings she had from her previous work. Aside from rice, she also has pigs. 

She is requesting a loan of PHP12,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy 5 sacks of rice seeds, 2 bags of urea fertilizer, and 2 bags of sulfate. The loan will definitely help Lilian have a better harvest. In this way, she believes, she can better support the education of her children.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people start and have their own businesses. Lilian enjoys having access to CEVI credit assistance, training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase 5 sacks rice seeds, 2 bags urea fertilizer and 2 bags of sulfate.

loans.name: Thi Xuyen

texts.vi:
Chị Đào Thị Xuyên  năm nay 61 tuổi, chị là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2006. Gia đình  chị có 3 con đã trưởng thành. Hiện tại công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị là từ chăn nuôi lợn  với thu nhập 2.000.000/tháng
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua 20 con lợn giống và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. D. Thi Xuyen, 61 years old, has been a member of the TYM Fund since 2006. She has 3 grown-up children. Currently, her family mostly relies on rearing pigs for a monthly income of 2 millions VND. This time, she would like to borrow 9 millions VND to purchase animal feeds and 20 more pigs to breed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing pigs

loans.name: So

texts.en:
V. is 56 years old and a resident of Siem Reap Province. He is the father of three children: all of them are single and under his care. He is married to Nai, 55, who earns a living planting vegetables behind her house.

V. owns the bass speakers for ceremonies and party service with only his non-roofed truck. The villagers know him a lot for his service and his responsibility in his obligations. V. recently wants to increase his income because he wants to have a big house. So V. is taking a loan of US$ 550 to buy a number of bass speakers for his service. The loan will help the family attain a better standard of living.

loans.use: To buy a number of bass speakers for his service

loans.name: Thi Kim Dung

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Kim Dung  năm nay 24  tuổi, chị đang sống cùng chồng và 1 con nhỏ tại huyện Kim Động tỉnh Hưng Yên. Chị tham gia Quỹ Tình Thương từ đầu năm 2008. Hiện tại chị ở nhà chăn nuôi lợn còn chồng chị làm nghề lái xe thuê. Mức thu nhập hàng tháng của gia đình chị  là 2.000.000.Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua lợn và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. N. Thi Kim Dung, 24 years old, lives with her husband and child at Kim Dong village, Hung Yen town. She has joined the TYM Fund since the beginning of 2008. Currently, she rears pigs at home while her husband works as a driver. Her family's monthly income is 2 millions VND. This time, she would like to borrow 9 millions VND to purchase more pigs and animal feeds.

Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing pigs

loans.name: Thi Ngung

texts.vi: Chị Hoàng Thị Ngừng  năm nay 55  tuổi, gia đình chị có hai con đã trưởng thành và có việc làm ổn định. Chị tham gia Quỹ Tình Thương từ đầu năm 2007. Hiện tại cả hai vợ chồng chị đều chăn nuôi và trồng trọt tại nhà. Mức thu nhập hàng tháng của gia đình chị  là 2.000.000.Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm 2 con bò giống về nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs. H. Thi Ngung, 55 years old, has 2 grown-up children who already have stable jobs. Mrs. Ngung joined the TYM Fund in 2007. Currently, both her husband and her rear cattle and grow vegetables at home. Her family's monthly income is 2 millions VND. This time, she would like to borrow 9 millions VND to purchase 2 more cows to breed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cows

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Sarah F. M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children, 8 and 17. Sarah has been running a charcoal business since 2007. She sells charcoal, which are small, black pieces of dry earth that are used by many Tanzanians as a fuel to cook their daily meals. Women cook food in small coal pots, in which they arrange mkaa (charcoal), and add paper, dry grass, old plastic bags or kerosene in order to light them.

Because there is such a high demand for charcoal across the country, being a charcoal seller is quite lucrative! Sarah works at the business for 12 hours per day, seven days per week and is assisted by one employee. Sarah currently earns about US$ 150 from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase additional stock of charcoal. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Sarah thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. <> Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Purchase additional stock of charcoal

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
R. is 46 years old and a resident of Siem Reap Province. He is the father of two children: both of them are still young. He is married to Sinan, 40, who runs a business selling cooked food. R. is a local construction foreman and he has been in this business for more than two years. He is well-known because his experience inspires confidence and because of his knowledge of what's stylish.

R. recently wants to have a small shop for his wife's business. So R. is taking a loan of US$ 300 to build a small shop and to buy some cooked ingredients for his wife's business. The loan will help the family attain a better standard of living. R. was not available for the photograph so his wife, Sinan, is photographed instead.

loans.use: To build a small shop and to buy some cooked ingredients for his wife's business

loans.name: Thi Huong

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Hương  năm nay 33  tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ Tình Thương từ đầu năm 2005. Hiện tại chị đang chăn nuôi lợn, bò tại nhà. Anh Hùng chồng chị ngoài thời gian phụ giúp vợ chăn nuôi còn đi làm thêm nghề xe ôm để tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Mức thu nhập hàng tháng của gia đình chị đạt 2.000.000/tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm 1 con bò giống và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. N. Thi Huong, 33 years old, has joined the TYM Fund since the beginning of 2005. Currently, she raises livestock at home. Besides helping her out, her husband also works as a driver for hire. Her family's monthly income is 2 millions VND. This time, she would like to borrow 9 millions VND to purchase animal feeds and a cow to breed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cow

loans.name: Sarith

texts.en:
D., 40, is a villager living in Banteay Meanchey Province, Cambodia, where she has established a small family, living in a medium-size wooden house, since 1979. She is a good homemaker who cooks delicious foods and cares for the children. She is married with four children: two are married and live away from the family home and the others are single. One among the single ones has been running a beauty salon service to the whole district for several years.

D. is married to BunThoeun, 47, who is a local chef for wedding parties in the village. D. is applying for a $800 loan to increase her daughter's capital for buying necessary things for her salon. (D.'s husband is pictured because she was not available the day the photograph was taken.)

loans.use: To increase her daughter's beauty salon capital

loans.name: Chen

texts.en: Chen S., 39, is a rice farmer who lives with her husband and three of her children in Kampong Cham province. She grows rice and raises pigs to earn a living and is able to make about US$ 1.50 per day. Her husband has a business selling dirt and sand. On average, he makes US$ 6 per day. Two of their children are in school and one is a worker. Chen S. is asking for a loan to purchase sand or dirt to sell at a construction site; any remainder of the loan will be used to purchase a stock of gas for refilling.

loans.use: To purchase sand and dirt for re-sale

loans.name: Thi The's Group

texts.vi:
Bùi Thị Thế sinh năm 1954,(Mã số: 010107010058 ). Chị hiện đang sống cùng con tại thôn Lực Canh – Xuân Canh. Chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp, chăn nuôi gà và lợn, ngoài ra chị còn đi chợ bán hoa quả để có thêm T. nhập. T. nhập của gia đình chị là: 3.000.000 VND /tháng. Chị là một người phụ nữ rất nhanh nhẹn và tháo vát, được xóm làng yêu mến. Các thành viên trong nhóm đã bầu chị làm nhóm trưởng. Chị tham gia vay vốn chu kì này với mức vay là: 5.014.000 VND để đi chợ bán hàng và chăn nuôi thêm lợn gà. Trong nhóm chị còn có:
 Nguyễn Thị Mý sinh năm 1950, (Mã số: 010107010059 ). Chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp. Chị tham gia vay vốn chu kì này với mức vay là: 1.090.000 VND đế chăn nuôi lợn và gà.
 Ngô T. Thủy sinh năm 1984, (Mã số: 010107010060 ). Chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp, ngoài ra chị có bán hàng nước giải khát để kiếm thêm T. nhập. Chị tham gia vay vốn với mức vay là: 4.142.000 VND để tăng chăn nuôi và bán hàng.
 Nguyễn Thị Chỉ sinh năm 1959, (Mã số: 010107010061 ). Chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp. Chị tham gia vay vốn chu kì lần này với mức vay là: 4.142.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn và gà.
 Ngô Thị Lừng sinh năm 1962, (Mã số: 010107010049). Chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp, ngoài ra chị có đi bán hàng thêm để có thêm T. nhập. Chị tham gia vay mức vốn là: 4.142.000 VND để bán hàng ăn sáng.
texts.en:
Mrs. B. T. The (ID No: 010107010058) born in 1954, lives with her children at Luc Canh, Xuan Canh village. She mainly performs agricultural tasks such as raising chickens and pigs. She also sells fruits at the market to increase her family's income, which is 3 millions VND a month. She is a very active and nimble woman, loved by other villagers. Other group members voted for her to be the group leader. This time, she would like to borrow 5,014,000VND to sell fruits and raise more livestock. Her group also consists of:
  • Mrs. Nguyen T. M. (ID No: 010107010059), born in 1950, She would like to borrow 1,090,000VND to raise livestock.
  • Mrs. Ngo T. T. (ID No: 010107010060), born in 1984. She mainly works in agriculture, but she also sells drinks to increase her income. She would like to borrow 4,142,000VND to raise livestock and sell drinks.
  • Mrs. Nguyen T. C. (ID No: 010107010061), born in 1959. She would like to borrow 4,142,000VND to raise livestock.
  • Mrs. Ngo T. L. (ID No: 010107010049), born in 1962. She mainly works in agriculture, but she also sells breakfast foodstuff to increase her income. She would like to borrow 4,142,000VND to sell breakfast food.

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising livestock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mama

texts.fr: Cette dame habite le quartier de tokoin gbadagbo, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale dans son quartier. Elle est la seule à exercer ce commerce dans  son quartier  et elle à beaucoup de demande, elle doit rehausser son stock pour faire face à la demande c’est pour cela qu’elle demande à wages un crédit  pour acheter des marchandise pour son commerce. Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants
texts.en:
This is a lady who lives in the Tokoin Gbadagbo district. Her income-generating work involves commerce in grocery items. She is the only one in this business in her area, and she is in high demand. She must replenish her inventory in order to cope with the demand. That’s why she’s asking WAGES for a loan to buy merchandise for her commerce. She is married and the mother of three.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grocery items

loans.name: Sarorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarorn S. (in the picture with her daughter), 65, is a widow with six children: four sons and two daughters. Four of her children are married and live outside the family home and one son attends university and has a part-time job as well. Sarorn also has one daughter (in the picture) who is a widow with five grandchildren; all are living with her. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sarorn has been a silk weaver and a tailor since 1970. She sells her finished products in other provinces which are far away from her house and she sometime sells them to the middleman who sells them in the market in Phnom Penh. She is asking for a loan of US$ 1,200 to purchase a motorbike for her son to drive to school and work, and to buy silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her son and to buy silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Ramon

texts.en:
Ramon A. is a pig grower. He is 74 years old already. Despite his age, he still strong and able to run his pig-raising business. He has 6 children and almost all of them are married. His children also help him in his business. The profit is what he uses to feed and clothe himself and his family. He has been in this kind of business for 50 years now.

He is asking for a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. He will use the loan to purchase sacks of feed for the pigs. In this way, he can take good care his pigs for a good sale.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people start up and run their own business. They not only provide credit but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of feed for the pigs

loans.name: Anim

texts.en:
L., age 56, lives in Siem Reap Province and is taking a loan of US$ 700 to build a new house for herself and her family. She is the mother of three children: all of them are married and live in different houses except the youngest family who own a tourist (12 chairs) transporting service is living with her.

Loeng who works as a local primary teacher is the husband of L.. L. plants bananas and some kinds of vegetables behind her house. The loan will help the family attain a better standard of living.

loans.use: To build a new house for herself and her family

loans.name: Thi Dao

texts.vi: Chị Bùi Thị Đảo  năm nay 45  tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ Tình Thương từ năm 2006. Hiện nay cả hai vợ chồng chị đều chăn nuôi bò và trồng trọt tại nhà. Đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu chính cho gia đình chị với mức thu nhập 1.500.000/tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm bò giống và thức ăn phục vụ cho chăn nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs. B. Thi Dao, 45 years old, joined the TYM Fund in 2006. Currently, she and her husband both rear cattle and grow vegetables at home. This is also the main source of income for her family. Their monthly income is about 1.5 millions VND. This time, she would like to borrow 9 millions VND to purchase animal feeds and more cows to breed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cows

loans.name: Chamnan

texts.en:
Mrs. Chamnan Choeum, 47, and her husband, Mr. Sam-orn Phoeung, 51, married in 1984 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. One of their sons is a monk, one child is a garment factory worker, and another one attends school. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Chamnan has been a silk weaver since she was eighteen years old, a skill she learned from her sister. She also taught her husband to become a silk weaver. They sell their finished products to the middleman who then takes them to sell at the market in Phnom Penh. Chamnan is applying for a loan of US$ 300 to purchase silk material for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for her weaving business

loans.name: Mt Elgon Group

texts.en:
Charles L. is single. He is staying with his sister’s daughter. He sells chips at Mwenge. He started this business two months ago and works daily from 11am until 12pm. He is able to earn a monthly profit of around US$ 48.

This will be Charles’s 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He wants a loan to open another chips place.

\t Charles will share this loan with his loan group, Mt. Elgon, which totals 17 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Charles is 1st on the right behind standing in a white shirt.

loans.use: To open another chips place

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy and resell bales of shirts

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 50-year-old Grace F. L. from Dar es Salaam. She is a widow with one child, who is one year old. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because they are orphans.

Grace has been running a pharmacy since 1997. She works at the business for 16 hours per day, seven days per week. Grace currently earns about 100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase medicines in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. Grace thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Purchase medicines in bulk

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi: Chị Trần Thị Phượng  năm nay 32  tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ Tình Thương từ năm 2006.  Trước khi tham gia Quỹ tình thương thu nhập của gia đình chị chủ yếu dựa vào chăn nuôi, trồng trọt. Sau khi tham gia Quỹ, có thêm nguồn vốn vay chị đã mạnh dạn đầu tư mở cửa hàng may tại nhà phục vụ cho nhu cầu của bà con địa phương tăng thu nhập cho gia đình. Công việc đang phát triển thuận lợi đem lại cho gia đình chị thu nhập 2.000.000/ tháng  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm vải về làm may.
texts.en:
Mrs. Tran Thi P. is 32 years old. She has been a member of TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) since 2006. Before joining TYM Fund, her family's main source of income comes from raising animals and farming. After joining TYM, Mrs. P. was confident to use her loan to open her tailor shop at home to meet the needs of the villagers and increase her family income. Her business is very good, bringing her family a stable monthly income of 2,000,000 VND (equivalent to 122 USD). This time Mrs. P. would like to borrow 9,000,000 VND (equivalent to 550USD) to buy more materials to make clothes.

Translated from Vietnamese by P. Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: With a great struggle lives a family led by R., 65, who is the mother of two children: both of them are married and live separately. She is married to Soe, 66, who earns a living planting vegetables behind his house. R. owns a small shop sewing fashionable clothing, and she has been in this business since 2000. She lives in an old house. And because of her business, R. wants to upgrade her house so she is taking a loan of US$ 300 to build a house to live in. The loan, together with her business, will help her attain a better standard of living.

loans.use: To build a house to live in

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhorn S., 32, and her husband , Mr. Savoeun Un, 36, live in a small village across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married for 12 years and have two children: one son and one daughter. Their daughter is in grade two.

Sokhorn has been a silk weaver for nine years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village who then takes them to sell at the market in Phnom Penh. Mr. Savoeun Un has been a construction worker for fifteen years. Sokhorn is asking for a loan of US$ 600 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business and to build a bathroom for her family.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business and to build a bathroom

loans.name: Nguyen's Group

texts.vi:
Nguyễn Thị Ánh sinh năm 1955, (Mã số: 010107030019). Chị hiện đang sống cùng chồng và các con đã đi làm công nhân. Chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp, ngoài ra chị còn đi chợ bán rau, bán hàng khô có thu nhập ổn định. Thu nhập của gia đình chị là: 3.000.000 VND/tháng. Chu kì này chị tham gia vay vốn với mức vay là: 4.578.000 VND để đầu tư chăn nuôi gà. Trong nhóm chị còn có:
 Lê Thị Đông sinh năm 1970, (Mã số: 010107030020). Chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp, chu kì này chị tham gia vay với mức vay là: 4.142.000 VND để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn.
 Nguyễn Thị Hoạch sinh năm 1954, (Mã số: 010107030021). Chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp và đi chợ bán rau. Chu kì này chị tham gia vay mức vốn là: 4.142.000 VND
 Nguyễn Thị Xính sinh năm 1953, (Mã số: 010107030018). Chị chủ yếu làm nông nghiệp và đi chợ rau. Chu kì này chị tham gia vay mức vay là: 4.142.000 VND
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen T. A. was born in 1955. She currently lives with her husband and her children, who are all workers. Mrs. A.'s main job is farming. Besides, she also sells vegetable and dry food at the market. Thus, her family has a stable source of income of 3,000,000 VND/month (or 180 USD/month). For this loan cycle, Mrs. A. wants to borrow 4,578,000 VND (or 276 USD) to raise chicken. Other members in her group are: Mrs. Le T. D., born in 1970, is a farmer. She wants to borrow 4,142,000 VND (or 250 USD) to raise pigs. Mrs. Nguyen T. H., born in 1954, is doing farming and selling vegetables at the market. She wants to borrow 4,142,000 VND (or 250 USD) Mrs. Nguyen T. X., born in 1953, is doing farming and selling vegetables at the market. She also wants to borrow 4,142,000 VND (or 250 USD)

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Chan nuoi, nong nghiep

loans.name: Yi

texts.en:
Mrs. Yi H., 46, and her husband, Mr. Mi Loem, 46, who live in a small village along National Road Number Two about 13 kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1981 and have eight children: five sons and three daughters. One of them is married and lives outside the family home; three children are garment factory workers; one son is a security guard; two children attend school, and another one is still young.

Yi has been selling Cambodian cakes for two years. Her husband has been a fisherman for five years. He catches fish from the lake near his village. Yi is asking for her second loan of US$ 500; she will use this loan to purchase a new motorbike to replace the old one for her son to drive to work.

loans.use: To replace their old motorbike for her son to drive to work.

loans.name: Mrs. Phen  Noy's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nineteen people living in Phnum Lonteach village in Takeo province comprise this village bank, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. Phen N. is the 53-year-old village bank president. She is a duck breeder. Her husband, Mr. Mork Vasna, is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare field where he cultivates rice. Although they have different businesses, they still havent enough money to support their household well. Thus, Mrs. Phen N. decided to ask for a loan to buy pigs and pig food for her pig-breeding business to earn more income for her family. She has five children, two of whom are food sellers who own a small restaurant while the others are attending the local school.

Fourteen members in this group have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. EoT borrowers are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy pigs and pig food to  to earn more income for her family

loans.name: Yawa

texts.fr: B. yawa  habite le quartier de djidjolé, étant divorcée de son mari, elle travaille dur pour pouvoir subvenir aux besoins de ses 02 enfants. Elle fait comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de maïs et d’huile rouge, elle fait ce commerce depuis 1990. elle a besoins d’augmenter son stock de marchandises qui s’épuise, elle demande à wages un crédit pour acheter des sacs de maïs et d’huile rouge.
texts.en:
Yawa B. lives in the Djidjolé neighborhood and, being divorced from her husband, she works hard to be able to provide for herself and her two children. Since 19990, her business has been consisting in selling corn and red oil (palm oil). She needs to bolster her stock which is running low, and she's seeking a loan from Kiva's partner WAGES, to buy sacks of corn and red oil.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell corn and red oil (palm oil)

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en: Mrs. Tessie C., 40 years old, married, lives at Lower Langcangan, Oroquieta City. She has 3 children. Her husband started the idea of mango production many years back.  They also have an existing business of selling fresh farm eggs but due to financial problems, Mrs. C. joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative to access their loan facility. She has  received loans several times already. Now, she is applying for PHP 10,000 to buy pesticide and fertilizer to revive their mango production. She has many plans for the future. She dreams that one day she will be the one to supply mangoes to Oroquieta City.

loans.use: to buy pesticide and fertilizer for mango production

loans.name: Son

texts.en:
S. is 37 years old and a resident of Siem Reap Province. She is a mother of two young children. She is married to Hin, 45, who earns a living providing a service of bass speakers for ceremonies or parties.

S. is a local grower of cucumbers, gourds and pumpkin. She has done this for more than one year. She recently earns a lot of profit from her business and her husband's service.

She lives in a house in which some parts of the roof have holes. So she is taking a loan of $200 to repair the roof of her house for her family. The loan will help the family attain a better standard of living.

loans.use: To repair the roof of her house

loans.name: Dioneta

texts.en:
Dioneta A. is a pig grower. She started her business 47 years ago. She has 7 children. Her pigs are what helped Dioneta feed and clothe her family. Her husband is a farmer. Aside from pigs, they also grow "ITIK" or ducks. Ducks are in demand in their town. Everybody loves ducks. She has regular buyers to call anytime she wants to sell her ducks.

She is asking a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy more piglets and feed for her pigs. Some of the loan will be used to buy ducklings for her farm. The loan will truly help Dioneta expand the size of her business. CEVI is a non-profit organization and a partner of WorldVision Philippines that helps people start up and run their own businesses. They not only provide credit to their clients but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase piglets, ducklings, and feed for the pigs

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Hằng  năm nay 30 tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ Tình Thương từ năm 2000.  Trước khi tham gia Quỹ tình thương thu nhập của gia đình chị chủ yếu dựa vào chăn nuôi, trồng trọt. Nhờ có thêm nguồn vốn vay của Quỹ chị đã mạnh dạn đầu tư buôn bán thịt lợn. Công việc kinh doanh ngày càng phát triển cho thu nhập đều hàng ngày vì thế kinh tế  gia đình chị Hằng đang ngày càng ổn định hơn.Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm thịt lợn về bán.
texts.en:
Mrs Nguyen Thi H. is 30 years old. She has joined TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) since 2000. Before joining TYM Fund, her family's main income comes from farming and breeding animals. Mrs. H. uses her loan to invest in buying and selling pork. Her business is doing very well, bringing her a very stable source of income. This time she'd like to borrow 10,000,000 VND (600 USD) to buy more pork.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Samoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Samoeun R. is a villager in Kloung Tvear village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Kong Sophal, is employed in World Vision organization and he has a little salary.  Mrs. Samoeun R. is requesting a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband to drive to work. She is 27 years old and the mother of two children who are too young to work or study. Her husband is also in the picture.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her husband to drive to work

loans.name: Charles

texts.fr: Monsieur A. charles habite le quartier d’agoe telessou au nord de la ville de lomé, il  fait comme commerce la vente de farine de blé qui est très utilisée dans la cuisine  togolaise pour préparer la pâte,il achète les sacs de blé et transforme le blé en farine à l'aide d'un moulin il fait ce commerce depuis 2004. Il est divorcé de sa femme, les deux enfants qu’ils ont eu sont à sa seule charge. le stock de farine dont il dispose actuellement ne lui permet pas de bien faire face à la demande de ses clients, il demande à wages un prêt  pour l’achat de  sacs de blé.
texts.en:
Mr. Charles A. lives in the Agoe Telessou neighborhood in the north of the city of Lomé. His business consists in selling wheat flour, which is very much used in Togolese cooking. He buys sacks of wheat and turn it into flour using a grinding mill. He's been running this business since 2004. He's divorced from his wife, and he is alone in supporting their two children. The amount of flour he currently has does not enable him to meet customer demand, and he's seeking a loan from Kiva's partner WAGES to purchase sacks of wheat.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of wheat

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen C. is 31 years old and married with a child. She lives in Warri, Delta state, Nigeria. She is a hair stylist and sells hair cream and hair extensions. She hopes for a loan of $675 to purchase more hair cream and hair extensions to sell. Helen says "Thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair cream and hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi: Chị Lê Thị O.   năm nay 44 tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ Tình Thương từ năm 2007.  Chồng chị mất sớm chị đang sống cùng 2 con tại thị trấn lương bằng huyện Kim Động tỉnh hưng Yên. Hiện tại công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị O. là từ kinh dO. tạp hoá, mỹ phẩm với thu nhập 2.500.000đ/ tháng Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm hàng về bán.
texts.en:
This year Mrs Le Thi O. is 44 years old. She has been a member of TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) since 2007. Her husband passed away early, leaving her with two children, all of whom are living in Kim Dong province, Hung Yen city, Vietnam. Currently her family's main source of income comes from her sundry goods store (2,500,000 VND/month, or 150 USD/month). She would like to borrow 9,000,000 VND (or 550 USD) to buy more goods for her store.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: Cette dame réside dans le quartier d’adjinamoto non loin d’adidogomé, elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants.elle fait le commerce de charbons de bois , ce commerce est très rentable à lomé, elle vend à ses clients en gros et en détail, elle fait ce commerce depuis 1994, ce qui lui permet d’aider des fois son mari dans les charges du foyer, elle voudrait rehausser son stock qui s’épuise, elle demande alors un crédit à wages pour l’achat de sacs de charbons de bois.
texts.en:
This is a woman who lives in the Adjinamoto neighborhood, not far from from Adidogomé. She's married and the mother of five children. Her business consists in selling charcoal, a very profitable business in Lomé. Since 1994, she's been selling retail and wholesale to her customers, which, at times, enables her help her husband with the household expenses. She would like to bolster her stock which is running low, and so she's seeking a loan from Kiva's partner WAGES in order to purchase sacks of charcoal.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Paulina O. sells medicine and provisions. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan of $675 to purchase more medicine and provisions to sell. She is 39 years old and married with three children. She lives in Warri, Delta state, Nigeria. Paulina sends her thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine and provisions to sell

loans.name: Satt

texts.en: Mrs. Satt K. lives in Srae Boeung village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Phoeng Phorch, owns a hall which is rented for weddings, ceremonies, parties, etc. Since his business is doing well, he wants to expand it; thus, Mrs. Satt K. decided to ask for a loan to buy more supplies for her husband’s business. She hopes to increase their income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan. She is 47 years old and the mother of two children who are attending the local school. Her husband is shown on the left of photo.

loans.use: To buy more supplies for her husband’s business.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy A. sells medicine. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan of $825 to purchase more medicine to sell. She is 49 years old and married with seven children. Her husband is a teacher. She lives in Warri, Delta state, Nigeria. Mercy sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Top's Group

texts.en:
Saroen leads a group of three borrowers. She has four children, all of whom are single. One works in a garment factory, one works as a Global Apparels Limited employee, and the other two are students. She is a good manager and a responsible neighbor. She has recently had difficulties with her family's transportation. The family cannot always use a motor taxi driver. Saroen is taking out a loan to buy a motorbike for their transportation. 

The other group members are C., age 46, and P., age 19.  C. is employed as a garment worker, and is taking out a loan to renovate her house. P. is also a garment worker, and is applying for a loan to build a kitchen. They all live in Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family's transportation

loans.name: Rasidatou

texts.fr: Cette dame habite le quartier de didjolé et tient depuis 2007 un cafétariat qu’elle appelle « cafetariat rara amen », elle est très dynamique et parvient à subvenir à ses propres charges grâce à son cafetariat, elle a besoin de se réapprovisionner, elle sollicite donc un crédit à wages pour l’achat de produits nécessaires à son ativité de restauration et des casiers de boissons
texts.en:
This is a woman who lives in the Didjolé neighborhood. Since 2007, she's been running a cafeteria called "Cafetariat Rara Amen". She's very energetic and manages to support herself thanks to her business. She needs to resupply, and she's therefore seeking a loan from Kiva's partner WAGES, in order to purchase products necessary to her food-serving business, as well as cases of beverages.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beverages and other products for her food-serving business

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith D. has a small "basakan", a filipino term for rice field. She grows rice and other crops to support her family. Her husband, Renito D., is also a farmer. Together, they work very hard to pay for the tuition, books and other school needs of their children. Aside from rice, she also has a small eatery business, which she operates in her village to help her augment her income.

She is asking for a loan of PHP15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy sacks of rice seeds, fertilizers and herbicides. The loan will truly help her improve her harvest for the whole family's needs.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people start and have their own businesses. They provide credit to support clients' businesses, training to equip people in businesses, insurance for security, and help for developing businesses.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of rice seeds, fertilizers and herbicides.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria E. is 50 years old and is married with four children. Her husband is a caterer. She lives in Warri, Delta state, Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs like garri, pepper, etc. Maria hopes to expand her business and is applying for a loan of $675 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She sells at the Udu market in Warri. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Mchicha Group

texts.en:
Amina A., age 34, is divorced with three children, ages eight, five and three. She sells charcoal. She started this business two years ago and works daily from 6am until 7pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $149. 

This will be Amina’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to increase her capital and  repaid the loan successfully. She now hopes for a second loan to increase her stock by buying more sacks for charcoal storage.
 	
Amina will share this loan with her loan group, Mchicha, which totals twenty members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Amina is in a yellow dress at the top in the middle.

loans.use: To increase stock by buying more sacks for charcoal storage.

loans.name: Saing

texts.en: P. is 29 years old and a resident of Pursat Province. His wife Chenda, also 29, works as a farmer on her parents' local paddy field. P. has been a motor taxi driver since 2000, and is famous throughout the community for his good work. He is looking for a loan to buy a new motorbike for his taxi service. The loan will help his family attain a better standard of living.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for his taxi service

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy and resell various items

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary U. sells foodstuffs. She loves this business because she makes a lot of profit. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for the loan amount of $475 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She is 38 years old and married with four children. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more supplies for her husband’s business.

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en: S. Saodat first applied to the MicroInvest loan program in 2007. It was a difficult period for her. She was dealing with troublesome competition and financial difficulties, and she could not even pay rent on the trade outlet. Saodat took a business development loan and realized quickly that she could import a new assortment of goods. She went to China and arranged to import seasonal women's wear. Since then she is working with Chinese suppliers. Saodat sells women's wear and she has a good variety. Now she is requesting another business development loan in the amount of $1100 for 12 months in order to import the new seasonal garments from the Kyrgyzstan Republic. She thanks KIVA for its support and hopes for all the best in the future.

loans.use: new seasonal women's wear imports from Kyrgyzstan Republic

loans.name: Kossi Kwami

texts.fr: Ce monsieur habite le quartier d’adidogomé,il est un entrepeneur dans son quartier, il fait cette activité depuis 2002, il a reçu de ses clients des chantiers de construction de bâtiments qu’il doit executer, n’ayant pas suffisament de moyens, il demande à wages un prêt pour acheter des planches et des tecks. Il est père de trois enfants et sa femme est une revendeuse.
texts.en:
This is a gentleman who lives in the Adidogomé district, where he is an entrepreneur. He has been an entrepreneur since 2002. He has received from his customers some building construction sites that he must work on. Lacking sufficient means, he’s asking WAGES for a loan to buy planks and teak wood. He is the father of three children, and his wife is a retailer.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy some planks and teak

loans.name: Allan

texts.en: Allan G. is 29 years old, married to Marieta G. and blessed with two children. He lives in Pagatpat, Cagayan de Oro City in the Southern Philippines. He engages in fish selling. Most of his customers are in his neighborhood and in nearby villages. Being a father, he wants to provide for the needs of his family, but unfortunately his current income is not enough. He is applying for a loan from HSPFI amounting to $175 to purchase additional fish to sell, along with some aquatic food, in hopes of generating a higher income. This will be Allan's second loan with HSPFI and if granted, he can earn more income and provide a more comfortable living situation for his family.

loans.use: to purchase fish for sale

location.town: Pagatpat, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Hằng 41 tuổi. Chị là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương  từ năm 2007.  Ban đầu chị vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi gà nhưng hiện tại với thu nhập từ chăn nuôi và mức vốn vay lớn hơn chị đang đầu tư vào buôn bán đồ nội thất tại nhà. Anh Nguyễn Văn Hiền chồng chị  ngoài thời gian giúp đỡ vợ buôn bán  còn có thêm nghề hàn xì nên thu nhập của gia đình rất ổn định ( 2.000.000đ/ tháng) Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs Nguyen Thi H. is 41 years old. She has been a member of TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) since 2007. At the beginning, Mrs. H. used her loan to raise chicken. As her farm gets bigger and she is now qualified for bigger loan, Mrs. H. wants to use her fund to invest in furniture retailing at her house. Her husband Mr. Nguyen Van Hien, a solderer, also helps her with the store. Thus, her family income is pretty stable (2,000,000 VND/month, or 120 USD/month). She wants to borrow 10,000,000 VND (or 600 USD) to invest in her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Marifat

texts.en:
P. Marifat lives in the B.Gafurov region. She is married with four children. Marifat has been engaged in the livestock business for 30 years, so she is experienced in the business and has the appropriate knowledge that she uses in practice.

Marifat takes care of one milk cow, one bull and four rams. She also makes milk products that she sells in a local bazaar. Marifat wants to open a specialized trade outlet for selling self-made milk-sour products. Marifat applies to Kiva with the request of a business-support loan of 1400 STJ for six months to purchase the specialized milk-making equipment that permits her to use modern technologies to speed up the existing milk-making process.

loans.use: Purchasing specialized milk-making equipment

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia sells foodstuffs, provisions and drinks. She has been in this business for a long time. She is 48 years old and married with five children.

She hopes for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Mr. Sambok Yung Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty-one people living in Phnum Lonteach village in Takeo province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mr. Sambok Y. is the 29 year old village bank president. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land where he cultivates rice to earn a living. His wife, Mrs. Nouy Kim Chhroeun, is a duck breeder who owns a poultry business. Now she wants to start breeding pigs; thus, Mr. Sambok Y. decided to ask for a loan to buy pigs and pig feed for his wife’s business. He has two children who are enrolled in the local school. 

Ten members in this group loan are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those who have end-of-term loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy pigs and pig feed for his wife’s business.

loans.name: Naka

texts.fr: Cette dame  est mariée, son mari est un policier, elle est mère de 02 enfants, naka fait comme activité  le commerce de vin de palme qui est une boisson locale très appréciée par les togolais, elle fait ce commerce depuis 2005. son stock de vin palme est pratiquement épuisé, elle sollicite un crédit  pour se réapprovisionner, elle fait son commerce à la maison, parfois lorsqu’elle ne réalise pas beaucoup de recette elle fait son commerce de façon ambulante.
texts.en:
This lady is married, and her husband is a police officer. She is the mother of two children. Naka’s work involves commerce in palm wine, which is a local drink that is highly appreciated by the Togolese. She has been in this business since 2005. Her stock of palm wine is practically exhausted. She’s requesting a loan to resupply herself. She operates out of her house. Sometimes, when she isn’t realizing a lot of earnings, she operates door-to-door.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy palm wine for resale

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Mrs. Nene G., 55, is a mother of two. Her husband is a farmer but farming alone is not enough to provide for the needs of their family.

With her pursuing heart, she has opened a small variety store in their village. From the start, she used a small amount of her own capital but there's only limited stocks to purchase due to limited capital. Therefore, she is in need of funds amounting to PHP 11000 to purchase additional stocks and grocery items for her variety store in order to gain and generate more income to support her children in school and to meet her established customers' needs as well.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for her variety store

location.town: Pagatpat, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary O. sells akamu (pap) on a wholesale and retail basis to her customers. Akamu (pap) is a local delicacy that can be eaten with beans and bean cake. Akamu (pap) is made from corn.

She hopes for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more bags of corn to make akamu (pap) to sell. She also hopes to purchase one grinding machine. Mary is 48 years old and is married with eight children. She lives in Warri, Delta state, Nigeria. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of corn to make akamu (pap) and a grinding machine

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en: S. Saodat lives in the J. Rasulov region of Tajikistan, is married and has four children. As is the case with many rural women, she has received some education but is especially skilled in raising and managing livestock. Saodat takes care of two cows, one bull and two rams, and has been in this business for 15 years. She sells the milk produced by her small herd in the local bazaar. Saodat wants to expand her business and has applied to Kiva for a loan to buy yarn-making equipment so that she can make and sell warm socks.

loans.use: To buy yarn-making equipment

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: S. is 71 years old and the father of one child who is married and lives with him in Seim Reap Province. His wife, Lang, is 59 and owns a grocery shop. Since 2000, S. has made a living repairing vehicles and supervising a construction crew. He is a great father and a responsible neighbor because he works hard and never wastes time. Because this is the harvest season and prices are low, S. wants to buy rice which he will store for later use. He has applied for a $700 loan to buy more products for his wife's shop and to buy rice. The loan will help the family attain a better standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more products for his wife's shop and to buy rice to store for later use

loans.name: Regina

texts.en: Regina M. sells sarongs of various colours, and most of her customers are women. She hopes to expand her business and has applied for a loan to buy more sarongs to sell. She is 46 years old, married and has five children. She lives in Warri, in Delta state Nigeria, and wishes to extend her thanks to everyone who makes this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Cataag

texts.en: Mrs. M. Cata-ag is a 51-year-old widow who lives in Layawan, Oroquieta City. She has two children, and says that being a single parent is not easy. She works hard simply to survive and to meet the needs of her family. Her primary source of income is a general or "sari-sari" store. In order to expand her business and acquire more capital, she joined the Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative last June. She is grateful to Paglaum because her most pressing financial needs have been met. Now she is applying for a loan to buy canned goods and other basic commodities to sell. She believes she can look forward to a comfortable life in the future, if she can expand her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods and other commodities to sell to her customers

loans.name: Lach

texts.en: Lach L. is 71 years old and resides in the Kampong Cham province with her husband and three of her children. She sells rice noodles and grocery items from her home and is able to make US$5 every day. Her husband sells corn and earns approximately US$4 per day. They are also supported by two children who work as mechanics and garment factory workers. Lach L. would like to take out a loan to expand her grocery store by adding more items to meet her clients' demands.

loans.use: To expand a grocery store.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Hiền 25 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2002. Vòng vốn đầu chị vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi nhưng hiện tại hai vợ chồng chị đều đang  làm nghề sửa chữa xe máy. Đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu  chính cho gia đình chị với thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư  mua thêm phụ tùng phục vụ cho công việc sửa chũa xe máy của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs Nguyen Thi H., 25 years old, has been a member of TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) since 2002. Her first loan was used towards raising animals. Currently, both she and her husband are investing their time and money in their motorbike repair shop. This shop is the main source of income for her family, which is about 2,000,000 VND per month (or 120 USD per month). Mrs. H. would like to borrow 10,000,000 VND (or 600 USD) to buy more tools for her repair shop.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Gulbiby

texts.en: T. Gulbiby is a highly-respected small businesswoman who comes to MicroInvest with many recommendations as a good and reliable person. She raises livestock for a living and sells milk, yogurt and other diary products in the local bazaar in Kayrokkum, where she lives with her husband and four children. Her oldest daughters help her care for their small herd. Gulbiby is applying to Kiva for a loan to expand her business by buying milk-making equipment. She thanks Kiva members for their support and wishes everyone all the best.

loans.use: to buy milk-making equipment

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
"Success requires a lot of courage, hard work, patience and responsibility” says Corazon S., a 55-year-old rice seller from Barangay Sta. Lucia Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She lives with her husband, Benjamin S., and their three children. The first two children have graduated from college and are presently working abroad. The youngest is still studying in secondary school. Corazon hopes that her youngest will also finish college.

The only source of income for the family is farming. At times, they have experienced financial difficulty, especially when their production is very low. This is the reason why Corazon is selling rice in her village to earn an income for her family. She chose this business because she knows that rice is a common commodity required by every family. Moreover, immediate sales are projected; therefore, there is less concern about having to stock the rice. 

Corazon is requesting a loan of PHP5, 000 to maintain her small business. She believes she can become successful with proper maintenance and hard work.

loans.use: Business Maintenance

loans.name: Everlyn

texts.en:
“Life is what you make it mean. What you are now is the result of your actions.” 

This is the philosophy of Everlyn R. of Sta.Lucia, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She lives happily with her beloved husband Edwin R. and their two children, Charmaine and Charmon R.. The eldest is now in her second year of high school, while the youngest is a grade III pupil.

Everlyn manages a small 'sari-sari' store at home, meaning 'a small community store' in Filipino. Her husband is a jeepney driver. Both businesses are their major source of family income. At the store, Everlyn only earns an average of PHP750 weekly, while her husband's income from driving a jeep is fluctuating. At times, they are cash-strapped when their children require financial assistance for school. Thus, the couple want to improve their business in order to increase their income and satisfy their needs. 

Everlyn joined a lending institution to support their business and get some benefits offered by the microfinance institution. She is applying for a loan of 7,000 pesos to increase her store capital.

With financial support and hardwork, she hopes to make their business grow.

loans.use: To expand a community store

loans.name: Hoeun

texts.en: Hoeun S., 25, sells fruit in the local market in Kampong Cham province. She earns about $5 per day, while her husband, who is a a taxi-driver, earns $10 a day. This couple has two young children. Her husband usually gets her grocery items in bulk from the countryside. Mrs. Hoeun S. is seeking a loan to make two investments: to buy more groceries to sell and to built her own fruit store.

loans.use: To buy more groceries and fruit to sell.

loans.name: Thi Hoa

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Hoà 53 tuổi, gia đình chị có 3 con trong đó có 1 con đang đi học. năm 2003 chị Hoà tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Hiện tại  bên cạnh chăn nuôi gia đình chị còn kinh doanh thêm hàng tạp hoá. Anh Trọng chồng chị luôn giúp đỡ chị trong công việc chăn nuôi để chị có thêm thời gian đầu tư cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình.  Với mức thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng gia đình chị Hào đang ngày càng có thêm điều kiện để cải thiện cuộc sống. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư  mua thêm hàng về bán cho bà con địa phương.
texts.en:
Mrs. N. Thi Hoa, 53 years old, has 3 chilren, one of which is still going to school. In 2003, she joined the TYM Fund and started borrowing to invest in raising livestock. Currently, besides livestock, her family also has a small general store. Her husband, mr. Trong, always helps her in raising livestock so that she has more time to take care of the store. With the monthly income of 2,000,000VND, her family has been able to improve their standard of living. This time, she would like to borrow 15,000,000VND to purchase more goods to supply to the villagers.

Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing goods for general store

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther A. is 35 years old, married, and has two children. She sells kerosene in wholesale and retail to her customers. She hopes for a loan of N70,000 to purchase more kerosene to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith S. is a rice farmer. She owns a 2-hectare lot which she inherited from her parents. She is 37 years old and has 2 children. Her husband, Felipe S., is also a farmer. They grow vegetables aside from rice to support their needs. They have been tilling their land for 15 years. Her harvest is intended for their family's use. Sometimes they sell their harvest for additional income for their family.

She is requesting a loan of PHP15,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy for fertilizers and chemicals to increase her yield. The loan will truly help Judith to have a better harvest from her farm.

CEVI is a non-profit organization and a partner of WorldVision Philippines that helps people start businesses. They are provided with credit, training and insurance coverage to help their small businesses grow.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals.

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
36-year-old P. is a resident of Pursat Province. He is the father of four children who remain single. His eldest two cihldren help him with his work, while the other two are students. P. is married to Vutha, 41, who works as a local farmer. P. is also a local farmer working on a plot of farmland that was passed on from his parents since 1990. 

He is struggling as his family faces difficulty with high expenses incurred from plowing the field. P. is tired of hiring his neighbor's buffalo to plow his own field. Therefore, he is asking for a loan to buy a pair of buffaloes to plow his farmland.

loans.use: To buy a pair of buffaloes to plow his farmland

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Sorn S. is 34 years old and married with one young child. She lives in Kampong Cham, Cambodia with her husband. Since 2007, she has been selling sugar cane juice from her home to earn a living and is able to make about US$4 every day, while her husband is a motor-taxi driver and makes approximately US$5 per day. Sorn S. would like to take out a loan to replace an old and unreliable motor-taxi for her husband. The old one uses a lot of gas and needs many repairs.

loans.use: To replace an old motorbike.

loans.name: Efe

texts.en:
Efe O. sells rechargeable phone cards and accessories. She wants to expand this business; therefore, she is asking for a loan of N60,000 to purchase more rechargeable phone cards and accessories.

Efe is 32 year old mother of two children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards and accessories

loans.name: Suha

texts.en:
Suha A. H., 24, is a dedicated wife and mother. She lives in Nablus city in Palestine. In order to better support her three children since her husband does not earn much in his work, Suha decided to open a small store where she can sells gifts, perfumes, and other goods.

Suha is interested in expanding her main financial source by purchasing more goods for her store. She is requesting a loan of 1000 USD. Suha thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Purchase more gifts and perfumes for her store

loans.name: Thi De

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Đệ 37 tuổi. Chiịtham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2003 . Hiện tại chị Đệ đang kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá kết hợp với chăn nuôi lợn, gà tại nhà còn anh Phúc chồng chị làm nghề xe ôm. Đây cũng là những công việc đem lại cho gia đình chị mức thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư  thêm vốn cho cửa hàng tạp hoá của gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs. N. Thi De, 37 years old, joined the TYM Fund in 2003. Currently, she takes care of her general store as well as rears pigs and chickens at home while her husband is a driver for hire. These activities bring about a monthly income of 2,000,000VND for her family. This time, she would like to borrow 10,000,000VND to invest in her general store.

Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investing in general store

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
“Nowadays, we are facing difficulties, especially in terms of the economic crisis,” said Evangeline. But as a responsible mother, she has the strong determination to combat poverty, with the support of her Rolando. She also believes that “poverty is not a hindrance to success” thus, they must strive very hard to overcome their life struggles. They live in a rural place located at Barangay (township) Sta. Lucia, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. With her husband who is a carpenter, she is blessed with five children namely: Vina Muriel, Vida Gueen, Laarni, Ceasar, and Ryan. The first two children are in secondary education while the others are in elementary education.

In their simple village, Evangeline manages a rolling store business; this is where they get financial resources to support their needs in the family. She wants to improve her business to increase her income for the sake of their children who are currently studying. With this in mind, Evangeline hopes to access a loan of PHP 7,000 to expand her rolling store business.

"Keep trying, finally," says Evangeline "so we’ll achieve success."

loans.use: Business Expansion

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
"Life is becoming difficult due to the economic crisis," says Francisca G.. She also said that if we have the five elements of success such as discipline, unity, patience, industriousness and sacrifice, we can defeat poverty.

Francisca and her family are living in a mountainous area near the riverside located in the village of Kinacao, Baretbet, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Oscar and they have six children. Four of them are already college graduates and two are high school students.

Francisca manages two kinds of businesses: a general store and a fish vending business while her husband is maintaining their piggery and poultry businesses. The couple is doing their best to improve their businesses, especially since they only have few competitors in their area. Francisca is hoping to borrow at least 5,000 pesos to buy rice that she will sell retail and also to start in the electronic load business. This will not only increase her income but also to meet the demands of their customers for their basic necessities.

loans.use: To purchase rice and electronic load business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth M. is a vendor of vegetables and traditional snacks and delicacies in their village in Uddiawan Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. Her husband Crisanto is working as a farmer. She and her husband are striving to live a progressive life by improving their small enterprises. She usually roams around their place going from one house to another to sell her products and earns a weekly income of PHP 600 that she uses as rolling capital in making traditional snacks. She dreams of buying her own pedicab (a bike with three wheels) that will be of great help to her vending business. However, she lacks capital for her business improvement, thus she is hoping to borrow PHP 5,000.

“If there’s no pain, there’s no gain,” Elizabeth said. She has proven this quotation in the past years in which she really had a hard time sending her three children to school, but with the cooperation of her husband and children, she has been able to send them to school and have them finish their studies which are their greatest accomplishment.

loans.use: Business Improvement

loans.name: Deona Ann

texts.en:
“To become successful in life” is a simple ambition that every individual hopes to achieve, just like Deona-Ann M. of Barangay Salamague, Lamut, Ifugao. She is a hard-working mother who has this great ambition for her family, but how? Deona Anne asked herself. She is challenged by the prevailing economic crisis but never loses hopes in seeking good business opportunities for she believes that, if “there’s a will there’s a way”. This quotation encourages her to work hard and to find some possible solution for the attainment of her goal.

Her business is selling vegetables in her cogon-made (a kind of grass used for thatching) vending stall in front of their house. Her husband Leonardo M. is a simple farmer; both are working hard for the success of their family and sending their children to school. She plans to improve her business and to increase their agricultural products in order to gain more income for the sake of their children.

There are lots of micro-finance organizations where she lives, but she chose to join ASKI where she could seek financial support for her vending due to its programs and benefits and because it is a Christian development organization. She is now asking the lenders for financial support of PHP 10,000 that she can use as business capital for her farming business.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Nikolay

texts.en:
Nikolay is married with one son. He sells men's and women's shoes at the central market in Zaporozhye city. His profit is 3,000 UAH per month.

Nikolay has been in this business for 10 years. He started small and now has two business locations in very good places at the market. Nikolay sets affordable prices and provides very good client service. This brings many repeated clients to his business and helps him to make enough money for his family's needs.

Nikolay would like to borrow 10,000 UAH to purchase a spring collection of shoes. He hopes to make additional profit and improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase a spring collection of shoes

loans.name: Mrs. Mom Marm Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank, which consists of twenty members, is located in Preaek Doung village in Kandal province, and they plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Mom M. is the village bank president, and she was selected by the members. She is a fruit seller in the local market. Aside from this business, she owns a phone service for people. Her husband, Mr. Bey Sopheap, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he cultivates both rice and vegetables. However, he now faces an obstacle because his field is infertile and this has damaged his crop. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Mom M. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, and she will use the rest of money to purchase gasoline to use to water the field and make her crop more productive. She is 42 years old and the mother of three children who are attending the local school. Mrs. L. Loem was not present to take out a loan but her husband was, so he is presented in the picture.    

One member in this group loan is end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those who have end-of-term loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline.

loans.name: Kwami

texts.fr: A. kwami est  un monsieur qui habite le quartier d’adidogomé, il tient un cafétariat non loin de la rue qui passe à côté de l’église de Zion tio, il souhaite mieux exploiter son cafétariat et demande à wages un prêt, son activité marche bien, il a une clientèle considérable surtout les jeunes célibataires de son quartier.il est divorcée de sa femme et les deux (02) enfants qu’ils ont eu sont à sa seule charge.
texts.en:
A. Kwami is a gentleman who lives in the Adidogomé district. He has a cafeteria not far from the street that goes right by the church of Zion Tio. He would like to get more out of his cafeteria and is asking WAGES for a loan. Business is good. He has a considerable customer base, especially among the young unmarried people in his area. He is divorced from his wife, and he alone supports the two children they had.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy the necessary goods for his cafeteria

loans.name: Mr. Meng Tuy Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people living in Preaek Doung village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes.
